cons: The threat of layoffs has loomed constantly for many years while jobs are simultaneously being offshored to India, the Philippines, China, etc.  Consequently, morale is very low and overtime is high among client facing teams as they struggle to keep clients happy in the face of the offshore challenges.

job_title: Mutual Fund Accountant in Boston, MA
pros: Entry level position as mutual fund accountant.  Good for post bachelors and hit the ground running.  Good overall base understanding of financial world.  Depending on work 10-6.  Never need an alarm to wake up. ( Year 2009)
cons: Low pay.  Boring work.  Sitting in front of computer.  Depending on funds you can have a busy day or you can have large gaps of time in your day.  People tend to get stuck there and their outlook on life becomes dull and it can have an impact on their well-being.   Year 2009)

pros: You will learn a great deal at this company. I personally learned a ton from the ETF department. Some of the benefits are great.
cons:
Hours are aweful depending of your team.(my hours were supposed to be 10-6 but I regularly worked 10-9, 10-10) I did get overtime which sounds like I would be making tons of money however my hours would regularly be modified to avoid paying as much overtime.(for example my boss would keep me till after 9 all week and then on Friday they would tell me to come in later so that wouldn't have as much overtime.
Management is horrible, they offer to help which is good but the changes are rarely implemented.
I was being heavily overworked and was easily doing the job of 3 people.

review_title: I only see a small piece of the pie, but I don't like it
pros: I'm in State Street Global Markets as a contractor, so I can't comment on the benefits because I'm not familiar with them, but as a workplace environment, it's a tough place to guage- there's really no uniformity to the way things are run. This can be a benefit depending on which department you're in and who you're working under. I'm able to work from home sometimes, and the lack of process in what I'm doing makes it easier for me to implement my own ways of doing things. The money is pretty decent as well. I'm a contractor, but I'm working 50 hours per week.
cons: Management management management. Some of Senior Management is great, and some have no idea how to run a staff or how to put good middle management into place.

job_title: Fund Accounting Manager in Quincy, MA
pros: This large, stable, American financial services company is an excellent place to develop a long term career within the so-called buy-side of the street.  The company's focus on institutional investors provides opportunities to learn about complex investment strategies used by sophisticated investors, yet still allow a decent work-life balance away from work.
cons: This company is very much Boston-based. Away from Massachusetts, opportunities for advancement are few and a branch office mentality is evident.  The company does not do an effective job at retaining young talent, often giving them great assignments to develop themselves, only to see them walk away for more money in different departments or competitors.

review_title: Prestigious company and treat there employees well.
pros: Get to take the initiative to learn much more about the market and the other sources with in the trade processing unit. Get the opportunity to help others perform at a quicker pace, and get great help from the upper management.
cons: Should give more exposure to the market, and should respect the employees that know much more than the senior associates and should give them the recognition they deserve; which could consist of promotions, or any sort of compensation to show his/her appreciation of work.

review_title: Many different job opportunities throughout tenure at State Street
pros: I joined State Street in the 80s when the company was experiencing growth so there were opportunities to work different jobs and learn new skills throughout my tenure there.  Career development was important to employees and Human Resources encouraged managers to develop career paths for employees.  The goal was to keep good employees on staff at State Street.  There were a good number of long-term employees within the organization and they were well known.
cons: Over time longevity became less valued and employees with long histories with State Street were let go with each downsizing initiative the company undertook.  In summary:  State Street is a good place to work but get in, get your experience and get out.

pros: Hands on experience with significant responsibility at junior levels;  Hours are reasonable: Some good people at the VP level and below.
cons:
This company is cheap. Compensation is laughable relative to market; Obsessed with cutting every possible corner for short term cost savings -- outsource HR, outsource IT, outsource onboarding -- despite major long term costs of doing so. 

Retention is abysmal. Most leave after two years. 

Management does a horrible job of listening to employee feedback and concerns. Feedback loops either doesn't exist or are otherwise broken. 

"CYA" and "pass the buck" "finger pointing" culture. Most employees lack an ownership mentality and constantly seek opportunities to blame others for anything that goes wrong. 

Outwardly adversarial relationship between business and control functions.

Wildly inconvenient corporate policies designed by bureaucrats who will never need to deal with the consequences of their decisions without seeking any input from those that will.

job_title: Vice President in North Quincy, MA
pros: Good salary and benefits, you can work remotely when needed
cons: Poor internal communication, direction of the company is always changing, job is always in limbo, layoffs,

pros: Good place to start and get experience, but the longer you stay, the worse it gets.
cons: Long hours, many weekends, getting things done on time, accuracy on detail .. none of those items really matter to management.  State Street has become a firm of conspicuous nepotism and that is how they promote people.  In addition, they don't deal with those that have numerous HR incidents filed against them; if they are in the "favored" crew.  Lastly, they continue lay off people every month (last Wednesday of the month), and those that have the subject matter expertise.  Again, the "favored" crew are not touched and the left overs get stuck with the work (I was doing the work of 5 people at the end).

review_title: Environment don't even match  with Service Based Company
pros:
Transportation Allowance and Sodexo are not included in CTC
Company has good name outside
cons:
No work life balance.
Need to work on multiple projects, take multiple calls from home at night and at end of year says that is just expected.
Doesn't recognize employee.
The recognized employees doesn't know why they have recognized.
Environment is worst than service based company.
No team outings and No budget allocated to team.
Only Super man, He man, Bat man can meet their expectations.
Better avoid joining the company unless you don't have an option.

review_title: Fund Accountant Review of SST Boston Private Equity
job_title: Fund Accountant, Associate I in Boston, MA
pros:
- Good co-workers
- Friendly managament
- Good position to learn about banking and private equity
- Ample time off
- Bosses you can trust
- Fun environment to work
- Paid time-and-a-half overtime
cons:
- Limited challenges 
- Little to no room for growth or development
- Little to no room for internal promotion
- High employee turnover
- Poor starting salary and raise potential
- Few incentives or rewards
- Very little tuition reimbursement
- Poor "top management"
- In general, a frustrating and limiting place to work

job_title: Client Service, Associate in Boston, MA
pros: My coworkers are helpful and experienced, and the program I was hired into set each new employee up with a mentor who has several years of experience in the company. There are many training opportunities available for those wanting to further their education on internal programs as well as broad overviews of the industry. Upper management is very interested in feedback.
cons: The hiring process needs work; there was a huge gap between the job I accepted and the work I actually do. At my current position there is little internal mobility or opportunity for promotion, which is a problem for me as this is my first job out of college. Communication between departments can be tense, which causes a problem when a client needs something done urgently.

pros:
1. The policy is well in place for everything & have good information.
2. Corporate Culture is really appreciable.
3. Work from Home Starts from Senior Associate.
4. Pick and Drop facility (Only Cab) provided by Company itself which not your part of CTC & if you discontinue it then Rs. 3500/- will be credited to your account.
5. Zeta card, Rs. 1500/-
6. Salary as per Bangalore Location & it's okay okay but not sure about Hikes.
cons:
1. Infrastructure issues especially cafeteria.
2. Night Shift Allowance comes 1 month.
3. Laptops were not provided to all
4. Laptops are worthless & work too slow.
5. Punch In and Punch Out is worst as the system doesn't work properly.
6. Local IT Support team is not supportive.

review_title: Easy to get started but it takes a lot of work to move up in the company.
pros: Easy career mobility within the company. If you are willing to spend the time and effort then there are opportunities that are available. There are many different areas within State Street that allow for huge variations from job to job. I have held 3 different positions within the company and have been able to learn about a different area in each one.
cons: Very operations oriented which means the work is boring and repetitive. The starting slaries are too low. Most of the work should be either automated or moved overseas which means that there is going to be some downsizing at the entry level in the near future.

pros: State Street is a large Corporation which provides a wide array of opportunities and great benefits. The best aspect of the company is the opportunity for internal movement and growth which allows for learning different skill sets and exposure to the Financial Services Industry. I also enjoy the networking with other employees and the feedback that management provides in your career path.
cons: The one major Con of working at State Street is definitely the Salary. State Street puts a great deal of resources into there systems and technology and while doing this pay there employees less than other companies for the same job.

pros:
Benefits are great.
3 weeks vacation to start off.
Easy to move around the company horizontally and vertically.
Work from home capability.
Many employee engagement activities.
cons: Low moral and turnover due to frequent overtime, inefficient software and slow computers, management being self-serving and noncompetitive pay. Additionally, their are many management layers many of which are filled with inexperienced individuals who stuck it out and took advantage of the companies inability to attain and keep well qualified, knowledgable employees. Having been interviewed at different firms by accountants and was told, SS does not practice true accounting and the skills and software used does not transfer.

review_title: An employee is really just a statistic
pros:
Location is good: close to South Station, lots of options for lunch
Opportunities to work abroad if you are interested
Good work-life balance
cons:
High turnover for some teams. More than 70% of a team with about 12 people left within a year and a half: just the head of team and 3-4 others were still there. That tells you how people think of the place. 
HR controls everything. They can rescind an offer after making one for reasons like "the salary in our offer letter is too high after second thoughts."

review_title: Hierachy, politics  and powerpoint  define this company
pros: Average pay and benefits. Some opportunities for internal transfers.
cons: I worked for Global HR department. The culture and environment in this organization is declining and just feels sad. Management power wars are obvious and so is transferring of US jobs to "low cost locations" that will continue into the next year. My recommendation is to avoid this company if you want to control your how your career should be going (or not).  Also noticed archaic management skill sets, where there is no respect for employees or individuals and you cannot communicate to management unless you have a specific powerpoint and maintain a strict minute agenda at the meeting to speak. Certainly not an environment that promotes and rewards ideas from within. Consultants and third parties are respected more than internal employees and management makes it known.

review_title: Not a bad place to work...
pros: I don't know about other groups within the bank, but the one I work in is enjoyable. You can come into the company not knowing a whole lot about the business world and the market and you can learn a lot very quickly. Also with employee turnover being somewhat high it's easy for those who stick around be be promoted. Since joining the group in September 2006 everyone in the group who was a Fund Accountant at that time who is still with the company is now a Senior Fund Account and the pay raise from the promotion is quite decent. I went from about 34.5K to 42.1K
cons: There are times when there isn't much going on to times when we're swamped. You really have to take the good with the bad.

pros: The work varies day by day.  Flexible Work Schedules.  Culture has improved over last few years.  Plenty of job opportunities and ability to transfer oversees.  Recent layoffs have removed lots of bad management.
cons: Lower then average pay.  Decreasing benefits, i.e. no more Pension, limited tuition reimbursement, increasing healthcare costs.  Large disconnect between upper, middle, and lower management.  During normal economic times, there is a lot of turnover.  Communication across divisions can be difficult.

review_title: Good place to start, but difficult to move up the corporate ladder...
pros: It's a very relaxed and comfortable atmosphere, almost collegial, although that can also be a negative aspect.  The benefits (health, dental, vision, 401(k), CharleCard, etc) are numerous.  Most managers are flexible with hours (people usually come in late) as long as the work gets done.  Lots of free time.  Overall, it's a good place to start off your career, but it may be frustrating if you're trying to advance.
cons: The pay is lower relative to people holding the same position in other companies.  There is little opportunity for growth and career advancement within the company.  There seems to be favoritism in the selection for promotions.  Employees are not rewarded (promotions, bonuses) proportionately for their efforts.

review_title: It’s good for takeoff but you have to be really desperate to stay there for longer
job_title: Senior Fund Accountant in North Quincy, MA
pros: Benefits are great and the right off the street possibility to work with the biggest clients. Other than that it’s really fast paced and well technologically equipped place.
cons: The high rollover at State Street is really certified by the fact that people that are with company about three years are considered long ‘distance runners’ and treated as a knowledge compendium. I have seen too many good talents to leave because of the low pay grade and almost no way for promotion. Consider this company as a good start up but do not stick for longer.

review_title: Overall, pretty good, but I feel I can make a bigger impact elsewhere.
pros: It  depends on the group you get placed into. There are many good leaders and managers scattered around the organization. If you are fortunate enough to work with these individuals, do what you can to learn from them. There are tons to be learned and most people see this organization as a stepping stone to further their careers. It is true, in that respect, but it's up to the individual to be proactive, learn, and to fight to earn what's deserving to him/her.
cons: Most people gripe about it, but the salary is subpar compared to SSC' competitors in the industry. Also, it can be frustrating when dealing with less-than-motivated colleagues and excess amounts of overtime.

review_title: Can I please have those 3 years of my life back
job_title: Mutual Fund Accountant in Boston, MA
pros: Entry level position of a mutual fund accountant is fairly easy to get and provides a good foundation for experience in the industry
cons: It is completely luck whether you get a disgruntled manager or not. I have had 3 different ones within the company and only 1 was good, the other 2 made the job unbearable. It's not somewhere where people care that they work, it's somewhere where you end up realizing you should move on from. I can tell you, you will print out about a forest worth of paper over your career and consequentially set it aside in a box where it will sit. They will climb the walls of the office and storage rooms and eventually be taken away. Most days I often thought I was making someone a good chunk of money with all  the derivatives and options I would book, but it was merely at my own expense.

review_title: Low stress environment for the most part, but low learning opportunity if asset servicing isn't your career
pros:
- Most employees are open to help if you ask for it
- Very little interaction as everyone seems to keep to themselves or their own group
- Company HR does make an effort for interns to go to large events and get to know people in the company
- Interns are paid fairly well ($12-15 an hour)
cons:
- Workload can vary dramatically based on what group you are in
- Difficult to apply experience to broader finance if asset servicing isn't your field 
- Entry level compensation for full time work is not competitive, especially given city location
- It doesn't seem like any of the folks that join the company straight from school actually wanted to end up here

pros: First 10 years, great environment and lots of community and inclusion activities. Flexible Work Arrangement Program a plus. Majority of employees are totally dedicated to company and work extremely hard.
cons: Financial crisis and regulatory landscape, plus changes in executive management, have provided a very unsettling employee culture. More and more difficult to get promoted to VP, Managing Director and SVP. Constant uneasiness about "will I be on the list" and get let go this month?" Losing lots of highly knowledgeable, talented employees.

pros: There are fantastic opportunities at State Street. The training program is extensive, the company is huge and encourages movement, and there is a strong focus on networking. If you are willing to work for it and have the right skills, you can move up quickly.
cons: The company culture is that of workaholics. This comes all the way from senior management down to associate level employees. There is no work-life balance at all, and this isn't going to change. The pay is also below market, which State Street has recognized but doesn't plan to adjust. If you're aware of these issues it can be a great place to work, but most will not stay long term.

review_title: it's an okay place to work
job_title: Operations Manager in New York, NY
pros:
laid back enviroment.
you can't get fired for being incompetent.
Don't need to work extra hard.  See my comments in the Cons section
cons:
I worked hard and my annual reviews always reflected this.  I had continued to receive very high grade on my performance reviews and was well regarded by my peers and directors.  The accolades were fine and dandy but let's face it, the pats on the back and positive words don't pay my bills!!!!  The freaking place is god darn cheap with the money that it's not even funny...
If you're an above average worker you will get the same compensation as the person next to you who may not have put in the same hours or the energy into work.  I have seen this happen two years in the row and I didn't want to wait around for another year

pros: I can't really think of any other than it might look good on your CV
cons:
Middle Management (AVP level) like to play mind games with there staff, you are constantly lead into a false sense of security which becomes obvious when appraisals are taking place

The hours are crazy, you are made wait to share a taxi home with someone who lives near you so it saves State Street money (they are meant to pay for a taxi home for staff if they work after 8pm), I was regularly working until midnight and back in again the next day at 9am with no thanks or appreciation for doing so. You are expected to work the extra hours and be happy about it, but this will not be said to you beforehand in the interview. 

The whole place is overloaded with graduates who are happy to pretend there on the apprentice and have no limits to their self worth. They will also gladly work 14 hour days and think this is normal.

review_title: Transitioning from Public Accounting into Private Equity Accounting
job_title: Senior Fund Accounting Analyst in Atlanta, GA
pros:
Salary & Benefits
State Street offers above average salaries and benefits at the Senior Level that is unbeatable.

Work Environment
Everyone in the Atlanta office has a great attitude! It all trickles down from management all the way to the youngest intern.  That positive demeanor around the office promotes quality work and comradery.  The Atlanta Real Assets Fund Services group as a whole niche is volunteering and giving back. On a quarterly basis you will find some type of event being coordinated by the office to better our communities, outside of work.

Volume of Work
Depending on the demand of the client volume can be high to moderate. I have worked on several funds within the last year and I can say that the client enjoys driving efficiency.  The perk at the senior level when there is a high volume of work or the time spent for process improvement, overtime pay is offered.


Flexibility (Life/Work Balance)
State Street is a big advocate delivering timely deliverables but also ensures you are taking care of you as an individual. One of the appealing items that were shared with me during my screening process is the ability to work remotely when needed.  I can attest that perk is official depending on team setup.

Opportunities

When I was hired by State Street I was brought on to be a part of a new sub business line of the PE/Real Assets group; Infrastructure Accounting.  Within in my first year I have witnessed how expansive and promising this role is.  At the Senior Level in Industry you would not be expected to be involved in some many processes end to end.  That includes on-boarding new clients, on-boarding existing clients with new funds, day to day fund accounting and administration, and consulting with the client on complex task.
cons: Rest assured, State Street Atlanta has done a great job bringing in new candidates that are competent, who has well-rounded characteristics and is willing and able to move along the team for the better without disturbing a strong foundation that has been set.

review_title: Great place to start for those with little or no experience
job_title: Custody Specialist in Kansas City, MO
pros: State Street is great place to start for those who have little or no experience. You will learn quite a bit from the type of work you do. You have opportunities to seek different a position or a promotion in other departments.
cons: Pay is very low. You will be very busy.Turnover is high. The work that you may not be related to what you learn in school. The company moved from client-based to function-based. This yields repetitive daily work and less learning opportunities .You used to learn much more when you do much more for the client.

review_title: I've seen the Co. destroy families with the O/T & then lay them off after >20 yrs. of sacrifice to hire cheap labor.
job_title: Client Service Associate in Quincy, MA
pros: Abundance of knowledge gained & looks good on your resume
cons: Underpaid and overworked w/ high turn around.  If you are receiving a decent salary you realize you have limitations on other opportunities as the other dept. wont accommodate your salary due to budgets.  So you continue to get good PPR  with a slither of hope you wont be stuck in your existing department while waiting like a sitting duck to get laid off.  Don't worry SS will rehire you but not any where near what you were previously earning.

review_title: The good, the bad, the average
pros:
It's a good place to start as no experience is needed for entry level (for which salary is so-so but for fresh graduate is ok). Below pros will heavily depend on the team/department/location you're in, but in general:
- friendly and supportive team members
- work from home possibilities (even in daily ops)
- in theory you've got access to vast amount of training courses
- chance to finance postgraduate studies
cons:
- constant staff changes
- lack of good entry training for new staff
- lack of time for projects not directly related to daily process
- a lot of overtime required
- limited options for promotion (starting from A2 to SA promotion)
- no reason to stay in this company if you'll have an offer from competition

job_title: Accountant Specialist, Senior Associate in Kansas City, MO
pros:
This is a great place to get started and are eager to learn about finance/accounting; it will allow you to get exposure to different aspects of the industry. 

The place truly lets you make the most out of your experience there; you get to decide if it's good or bad.

Amazing benefits, good people if you're on the right team.
cons:
Base salary is mediocre at best, but the benefits make up for it.

If you're responsible and good at your job, it becomes very demanding as you're almost required (without being asked/told) to pick up the slack for other employees that don't devote as much as you do towards getting results.

HR will stress a work/life balance but that ultimately depends on which team you're placed on.

review_title: Global firm with many opportunities to advance your career
pros: Very flexible working conditions, good work life balance. Staff are easy going and great to gets along with. Company has a variety of employees networks and affinity groups which makes it easy to meet new people. Despite new regulations, the firm is working hard to innovate and growth their business. There are many opportunities to do work that will be rewarding. Also they are working to recognize talent by implementing rotational programs for high performing staff. Many senior executives engaged with their staff and are willing to give advice or open mentoring. Active in the community.
cons:
- below average salary
- slow moving and bureaucratic, although the leadership is working to change this 
- very conservative, it's a challenge to advance new ideas

job_title: Assistant Vice President in Atlanta, GA
pros: Flexible work schedule and the ability to work from home, overall a stable; reliable workplace, ability to learn and work in a unique environment that is valuable in the marketplace.
cons: Always understaffed, no raises given in 2019, disconnect between decision makers and people actually doing the work and managing clients, little to no training provided to all levels of positions, most of leadership has been with the bank too long, clients are sold a product or service that is not the reality of what SSB is able to do, people that sell the business are not part of the client relationship after launch, the operating model is to work people as hard a possible until the burn out and they either become disgruntled or leave.   Again, consistently understaffed.

review_title: Come for the experience; leave for the money.
pros: Being a diversified company, State Street offers many positions from which someone can garner a lot of knowledge. However, once you're in a position, you are pretty much pigeon-holed, and are expected to do your job and not expect to  aspire to something better unless they thought of first, or unless you are related/friends with someone.
cons: If you are happy being just a cog in the wheel, and are willing to go along to get along, then State Street might be the right place for you. If, however, you are ambitious, then the many political structures you have to navigate to get ahead are particularly disappointing. Local management often hide behind Boston's skirts in order to avoid any unpleasant topic that they don't want to deal with. By the same token, Boston takes a hands off approach to operations. Great ideas get filtered so tight they are strangled. This is not a learning organization as claimed.

pros: It's a job and a paycheck/benefits.  You can get attention to detail/multi-tasking/Excel experience.  Also it's a strict 9-5 job.  I believe you get paid overtime, although it's rarely necessary.  The slight downside to this is that most of the time must be there for pricing from 4-5 every day, even Fridays on holiday weekends...
cons: I understand it must be challenging for such a huge company to organize, but if you are an intelligent/inquisitive person you will find yourself in a mundane role with little opportunity to take on more challenging work.  Very rarely will you find someone passionate about the company.

review_title: The name is OK for entry level resumes, but definitely not worth it
job_title: Mill Turning Mule in Kansas City, MO
pros:
- They'll take fresh college grads even in this economy
- Pays the bills (assuming you live the life of a hermit) and has decent benefits
- Gives you a reason to get up in the morning
cons:
- Meritocricy means nothing, seniority takes precedence over competence, initiative, and preformance in considerations for bonuses and promotions
- You WILL be managed by people who are clearly incompetent/stupid/insecure, and have been there for ages since they literally have no where else to go, and they know that
- Easy to be stuck in the back office trap, especially when most people around you have no ambition to do anything else and actually think they are "playing the corporate game"
- The work is basically glorified data entry, and future employers know that

review_title: Worst Company I have ever worked for disgusting culture.
pros: Good restaurant and employees (below management level) generally sound. Another pro is can get promoted if the type of idiot who enjoys working all night. Although treated like slaves don't beat employees although they might like to - to work you harder.
cons: Long hours - on my team average 60+ with a lot of all nighters - break Working Time Act all the time. Also break Health and Safety on pregnant workers. Constant monitoring by managers, work the living hell out of you, no training, crap coffee, money poor (avoid funds if starting out). Ignore company literature - no respect for employees, all goals about money and only care about money and send regular emails saying cannot do anything that costs the company money.

pros: Lots of very well paid and smart individuals both technical and at the business level.  Company does not hesitate spending money.
cons:
Huge competition exists at every level between old and new employees.  The old employees contributed in the past, remained loyal, but don't have nearly the same skillset of the newer employees.  

You see political games from executive VPs all the way down to the lower level workers battling it out.  Mainly the old groups just want to hang on another decade or so.  Is obvious.  Many new, young employees join State street, and don't last.  Is for a reason.

review_title: Great position to gain business experience out of college
pros: Great launching point for the start of a career.  If you need guidance, this is a place where you 'hand is held' and every step is outlined for you.  The promotion path in this area is clearly outlined, and if you work hard and prove yourself you will excel quickly.
cons: Oftentimes the work is very repetitive and employees burn out from this process.  Not everyone who is hired has the same work ethic and competence level, resulting in the 'better' people taking on more work.  Because this is an operations position, hours can extend into the late night on a frequent basis if any issues are encountered.  It is not abnormal to work a 12 hour day, although overtime is available.

review_title: Generally very rewarding and valuable to my longer time career.
pros:
Well organized, structured development team, good processes & procedures.
Good mix of development technologies and skillsets in team.
Opportunities to work on diverse projects both small and large.
Big DB work in SQL Server & Oracle.
Very experienced team, great team dynamic, everyone is friendly.
cons:
IT training budget was almost non-existant due to tightened budgets at a regional level
Very few opportunities to work 'outside the box'
Teams are being outsourced, and all the work seemed to be going that way too when I left.

pros:
Great Benefits and Company Policies (Education assistance and Fitness programs).
Decent salary considering the amount of work done.
cons: Promotions are based entirely on favoritism rather then your abilities. This causes to have managers that are incompetent and completely distant from your day to day work. Managers that are on a power trip. In fact, management is solely responsible for the high turnover rates due to employee dissatisfaction. Even senior management admits that the associates have more knowledge then the team leads and officers.

job_title: Core Operations, Senior Associate in Kansas City, MO
pros: Ability to work from home,  Paid volunteer time, Vacation, Benefits
cons: Raises and bonuses drastically decreased or ceased to exist over years, Outsourcing of jobs overseas,  Experienced staff with knowledge either leaving company for other jobs or being laid off

review_title: Work hard and you will move up - however the poor compenstaion is unfair.
job_title: Fund Accounting Manager in Boston, MA
pros: State Street is a good company for an entry level employee/recent graduate as many of your peers will be in the same situation. Good place to learn how to conduct oneself in the workplace and see the dynamics of a large corporation.
cons: The pay is the worst. Almost insulting. Management is always looking to find out why there is high turnover etc. I feel that some of the turnover from high performers is due to the lack of compensation. It is all well and good to be told you are doing a good job but not getting paid fairly for it is demoralizing.

review_title: Lots of growth opportunity but low salary and lots of overtime
job_title: Senior Fund Accountant in Toronto, ON
pros: High turnover so lots of opportunity to move up; plenty of business units if one is interested in horizontal movement as well; great benefits; management is very supportive of training and further education
cons: the biggest con is low pay and lots of overtime; my hours when I worked there were 9am-7pm during non busy season; and during busy season 9am-midnight on week nights and 10am to 5pm on Sat and Sun; 5 reorganizations during the 3 years I worked there; low staff moral due to high turnover

pros: It's a good place to start your career, easy to get into straight after studies. If you want, you can learn quite a bit of practical basics of finance. If you don't want, you can click F11 all day and still get paid. Company offers quite ok internal trainings, some opportunities of advancement and stability.
cons: Rather old fashioned and not used anywhere outside the company accounting system. If you don't want to be a small gear in a huge machine - stay clear. If you want opportunities to exercise your creativity and find your true self at work - stay clear. If you want a CV position that will help you reach executive levels - stay clear. In short - you are not an unique snowflake here.

job_title: Fund Accountant in Kansas City, MO
pros: The company promotes a social environment. It would be a great place for someone straight out of college looking for their first corporate job. Not a great place for long-term employment if you're starting from the bottom.
cons: Some negative aspects from my perspective of working at state street include a college-type atmosphere, lack of individuality, lack of consistent work throughout the day, and lousy hours for someone looking for good work/life balance. From day one it felt like everyone was just a number. They have significant turn-over which speaks for itself.

review_title: An alright place to start but you need to really hustle to move up
pros: Flex-work arrangements were pretty solid, obviously dependent on the working group you were in and if flex-work or work-from-home was possible and applicable.  The people at the company were generally pretty friendly and I didn't find it clique-ish that much.
cons: The most glaring con that the company globally is reducing it's employee base significantly over the next few years and a lot of positions will be eliminated.  Management generally doesn't recognize or reward good work, they only tend to notice employees if anything goes wrong on the client side. You will need to seriously shmooze and network to climb up, if you have the wrong kind of personality there you will struggle to move up.  If any work you do can be outsourced at all - your position is in serious jeopardy.

review_title: Trying to do the right thing, but...
pros: The company has a culture that values integrity and doing the right thing.  The employee training related to building and supporting this culture is thorough and effective.  I've often felt proud to work at State Street.
cons: The culture is highly bureaucratic and process-oriented, and the processes are slow to evolve.  This makes it very difficult to get things done.  The internal politics can often be brutal in the middle- and upper-management ranks.  Managers tend not to be hands-on in the technical realm, so they fall behind as technology evolves, and I suspect that results in insecurity that leads to poor decisions and more political infighting rather than less.

job_title: Fund Accounting Manager in Boston, MA
pros: Generous compensation packages are offered and are increased with advancement within the company; offices located within the heart of Boston make it a great place to be; numerous benefits and opportunities to participate in civic affairs/philanthropic efforts.
cons: Many roles involve monotonous workdays and daily deadlines that, until they are done each and every day, will require you to put in extra hours (senior associates and above are not eligible for overtime compensation).

review_title: Zero regard for employees or their future.
pros:
Financial services experience.
The ‘big’ name of State Street – (which meant more before everything became centralized or work was being constantly outsourced). 
Commute is good if you live in the city.
cons:
Disturbingly low pay; know your worth before you accept a job here. 
High turnover, unexpected and surprise lay-offs, not all but most managers I’ve met either don’t manage or horde knowledge. You have to dig deep, long and far to learn something new and relevant since all the work is divided into Centers of Excellence. Horrible employee rating system which is totally sewed. Overqualified people working monotonous jobs.

review_title: From HR team ,IT(infra & support), project and resource planning to it’s leaders, everything just sucks in India office
pros: Transportation (may be the only one)
cons:
-Unethical HR who will misguide and lie anything to on-board an candidate . Once on boarding is done, they will never ever show their face throughout ones tenure there. You will never be allowed to speak to any HR after joining. The HR support is again outsourced and for a simple thing one has to do several follow ups
-IT infrastructure is like we had in 80s May be, it’s slow, most process are manual. Don’t expect any support from IT teams, been outsourced, they are least bothered to resolve it. 
- Worst leaders: Most business leaders don’t deserve the given positions and had some HR issues in the past. They are arrogant, unethical, lacks etiquettes and are least bothered about their team, just saving their jobs and high salaries. From procurement to referrals they do fraud in almost everything possible(monitory non monitory)

review_title: A good place to work before the financial crisis
job_title: Assistant Vice President  in Boston, MA
pros: Benefits are fairly good - 4 weeks of vacation for officers, 6% match for 401(k), health, dental, etc.  The company is trying to institutionalize flexible work arrangements.  At the moment, it seems to vary from manager to manager.  There are people who have worked here for many years, which says something about employee satisfaction.
cons: It seems to be more difficult for people who need more work/life balance to advance.  The mood is fairly bleak these days due to layoffs, a decrease in bonuses and a salary freeze.  Employees are doing more work for less compensation.

review_title: Life at State Street could be better
pros: The company has a good work life balance for its employees. The hours are reasonable so that you can complete your work.
cons: You can only learn so many funds until get bored.  There are no opportunities to advance within the company. Upper management is hush-hush about what is going on within the company and its direction.  Whenever they have meetings, nothing gets accomplished.

review_title: Salaries are low, daily tasks are menial, overstaffed, and communication is non existent...A place for steady eddie's
pros: A place where you preform the same daily taks with very minimal variation and salaries are an industry low...by far. Good place to get your feet wet and put on your resume.
cons: The day's drag by due to overstaffed FA's. Less FA's would give employees work to do throughout the day, and an increase in pay would help retain talent.

job_title: Fund Administrator in North Kansas City, MO
pros: Some of the best benefits out there. A fantastic 401K match and solid choices for benefits. The environment isn't terrible and they used to sponsor several moral boosting events.
cons: The work is boring and mind numbing. It just repeats itself in cycles. You are either way to busy or literally doing nothing. Management doesn't seem to want to help employees advance. Most managers are great reviewers but terrible leaders. Work life balance is OK. Worst thing is probably the pay. There is a lot of turnover for a reason. When the market turns around and opportunities become available this company better look out and figure out a way to retain key employees.

pros: If you are a “yes man” (or woman) who “does as your told,” this may well me the place for you. If you have (or want) the cookie-cutter, white picket fence lifestyle you will fit in perfectly.
cons: Long hours and small raises are par for the course, as are dull, repetitive days. This place is the epitome of mediocrity; like Initech (Office Space) with a nice lobby. Don’t let the lobby fool you, though – it’s all down hill from there. If you dare disrupt the status quo by thinking outside the box or coloring outside the lines, your days here are numbered; which is a blessing in disguise. The culture here is toxic and staid.

pros: WFH, gain some limited experience within the industry. nice people for the most part. Some managers are good, others are not.
cons: Low pay with no upward mobility unless you're in the future focus program. Can work your a** off and consistently receive only "meets expectations" on your reviews. Will get told your promotion is a few months away, "just not in the budget right now", and see others move up at the same time. All about who your friends with. Most importantly, the cumulative effects of years long brain drain resulting from low pay and treatment of workers is in full force and readily apparent in some departments. Doesn't matter much as the bank has set their sights on automation and layoffs.

review_title: Good place to work but depends on the team
pros: Big company, multi-cultural, important number of associations every employees can join, good place for networking, challenging environment. Possible to develop new skills thanks to internal trainings (if your managers are willing to let you do it) and possibility to work on diversified tasks depending on the team.
cons: Not the best communication although they try very hard to improve. It just doesn't work. Depending on the team, you may not feel valued. Complex hierarchical organisation, too many people at senior management level/VPs in some teams with little number of people working on deliverables Rewards are not good regardless of long hours spent daily in the office to prepare deliverables with tight deadlines. This can create a bad atmosphere, staff can be openly not motivated, and senior management does not show any concern about it as if they don't care.

pros: State Street considers itself a technology provider to the financial services industry.  As an IT worker this benefitted me.  I got to work on some interesting projects.  I picked up some new technical skills along the way.  The pay was good, as were the bonuses.
cons:
In a word, bureaucracy.  No work gets done without filling out the right form and having it approved by one, but more often more, levels of management.

The long time employees there tended to have bad attitudes - complaining all the time.  This combined with the bureaucracy tended to be a morale killer.

Management had a very cavalier attitude toward night and weekend work.  It was almost as if they didn't expect us to have lives outside work.

review_title: Enjoyable for a time, but a career for most.
job_title: Client Service Associate in Kansas City, MO
pros: I enjoyed the people and the managers (especially the hire you go)  were very knowledgeable and usually pretty good at their jobs. The people are the main thing that made me stick around.
cons: The pay is horrible which is why the company's turnover rate is so high. There are some that make this place a career, but it seems to serve as a farm system for better paying companies.

pros: Overtime pay, work from home option, for a person right out of college and not having many bills to pay the salary is good.
cons: Benefits - you expect me to give up 100+ of my pay (which is weekly) no thanks, work-life balance - depending on your group you may be in the office til 9pm and may have to work weekends, the help desk - unless you like talking to a person that wont go off script to fix a problem expect many issues when you call, took over 3 months to finally get the proper access to everything.

pros: Flexibility is one of the few perks left at State Street. Work from home is available and flexible work hours are usually allowed. The drawback is that the flexibility is offered due to many required hours of unpaid overtime and frequent weekend hours.
cons: I've been with State Street for close to 20 years and passed on better jobs with more pay from competitors because of the work-life balance offered at State Street. At this point, work-life balance is non-existent and most departments are working on a shoestring. Offshoring is a disaster and the limited resources in the US are expected to pick up the slack. People are routinely working in excess of 60 hours per week and with monthly layoffs looming, morale is bad and people are constantly on edge.

review_title: Not a good place to work
pros: They will allow you work from home and every few years you may get also get a promotion, but only if you threaten to quit first.
cons: They claim that they are not getting resumes to fill open positions.  We have a constant wall of work ahead of us and no relief in sight.  Clients are upset because of the constant turnover and lack of client focus.  How can we focus on clients when we have 20-30 of them to take care of at any given time and a group of 6 when we used to have 30?  CEO says they are "listening" and will make improvements.  However, we have all heard that before.

review_title: A review from a long time employee (just short of 10 years)
pros: State Street was generous with time off, even letting employees purchase or sell vacation days at the beginning of the year. State Street is also very invested in the communities where they have offices, encouraging employees to volunteer (including offering paid days off for volunteer work) and give back to the community (including matching contributions to approved non-profit organizations).
cons: As the economy changed, State Street decreased staffing levels while increasing individual work loads. This resulted in employees often being overworked. In addition, there were more "bosses" than employees. Often the managers couldn't (or wouldn't) do the work the employees did so that if short staffed the managers wouldn't assist with tasks.

pros:
A lot of work to be done which makes the days go fast.

Quite good for flex time depending on the team you're on.

In general there are good people but, but many are disheartened.
cons:
Not enough people to do the work and becoming less all the time.

Bonuses are normally non-existent or nothing to write home about.

The amount of off-shoring at the moment is crazy meaning that there won't be jobs here soon, but mgt seem to think there will be... Would make you wonder how they got in these roles in the first place. Lies

review_title: My Take on Working at State Street
pros: State Street is a good place to work because the executive level of management is committed to efforts at diversification in terms of gender and national orientation.  They are committed to offering flexible schedules for most levels of employees to help with the work life balance.
cons: The problems arise at the divisional level of management.  It is my experience that they have very poor relational and communication skills.  My division leader is notoriously cheap because what she saves the company in expenses, increases her own bonus at year end.

review_title: State Street is an out of touch large corporate structured bank.
job_title: Associate II in North Quincy, MA
pros: They reward employees with opportunities to give back to the community.  Many departments offer a flex schedule for a better work/life balance.  Vacation and paid time off helps make up for the well below average salaries.
cons: Atmosphere tends to nurture and advance tenure instead of intelligence and hard work.  Very corporate driven and need multiple people to get an answer.

review_title: No longer a good place to work
pros: There are certain things that are constant...benefits, 401k, flexible work arrangements such as working from home
cons: Senior management has very little regard for those with valuable skills and expertise. Focus is purely on bottom line. People with decades of service are let go, functions are "transformed", which is another way of saying "we're going to layoff hard working Americans and send their jobs to India" where for what was done by one person in the US requires 3-4 "partners" to execute. Once the lower level positions are eliminated, senior management creates layer after layer of groups to oversee ridiculous "initiatives"

pros: Overtime to compensate for a mediocre salary.
cons: Over the past year my department has been on a hiring freeze with a real push back on back filling. Last year we were not offered raises or promotions and no discussion regarding that possibility in the future so people have begun jumping ship, but with the lack of replacing it has caused the people still here to be overworked and now more are looking to leave. Management has chosen to remain silent instead of being honest and open about the situation.

review_title: Overall good company to work for.
pros: They have an outstanding benefit package, strong upper and mid-level management, and you are valued as an employee. Communication lines are open between all levels of management an employees and even in difficult periods for the company, management does what it can for its employees. They are always tops in terms of technology giving employees the best tools in the industry with which to work. Promotions come primarily from within.
cons: Compensation at State Street is low compared to competitors which leads to high turnover levels among lower level employees. The lack of continuity can become difficult for first line managers in maintaining operational standards.

review_title: Absolutely the worst place I have ever worked!!!  Beware!
pros: They encourage you to volunteer two days out of the year paid.  Benefits are pretty ok.  Other than the free coffee, there's nothing else good.
cons: Management in the department I worked in was absolutely horrible. Everyone in my department hated their jobs and were miserable.  Managers manage through the use of fear, manipulation, and micromanagement.  Employees are successful if they can become yes-men, act like a robot, and become a slave.  If you have an opinion, however, you are doomed to failure.  Avoid working there at all costs.  It takes at least seven years to get one promotion.

review_title: OK place to start, terrible place to stay
job_title: Senior Fund Accountant in Boston, MA
pros: Easy to get a job with no experience, work from home is available if you have a good manager who allows it
cons: Huge focus on centralizing processes leaves you with a lot of experience in one area and almost no experience with anything else. It can be difficult to move on to another company if you stay there too long. A lot of promotions are based on who is next in line rather than who would actually be good for the position. Very poor compensation, my last bonus was 1% of my already low salary and actually getting tuition benefits approved is very difficult.

review_title: Worst company to grow within, less paid ever
pros: Good benefits and thats about it
cons: To many things to mention that are categorized as cons. Salary is so low, intern start at 15$ which is very good but once you are full time you start with the same amount which is disappointing. T move up is very hard. There is not rules that will make you move up. Its to much politics a lot of politics, horrible environment. There are ppl who have been for 2 year and become manager and there are ppl who have been for 5 years and they still associate level, the reason is the politics. There is nor rules or tests to be given in order to promote the most qualified ones, its so disappointing,

review_title: Good entry level, good benefits, not long-term, very low salary
pros: benefits package is good, vacation time. Good place to spend a year or two to learn the ropes of a specific area before leaving for a company that will actually pay you in something more than peanuts.
cons: Low-to-no bonuses, extremely low salary structure, makes it very difficult to stay or retain talent. Lack of compensation causes massive turnover. Constant re-shuffling of org structure, makes jobs even more cookie-cutter and unmarketable. Lots of outsourcing and cheapening of business strategy. Lots of downsizing for mid-to-high level management makes it difficult to expect good managers or retain good managers. Under-paid associate level employees make for a poor atmosphere.

review_title: Mutual Fund accounting has its good and bad: know what you are getting into
job_title: Senior Fund Accountant in Kansas City, MO
pros: At the Kansas City location most of the work is mutual fund accounting.  The good of this work is that the work can usually be performed at a moderate pace without having to take work home.  Also, since State Street is one of the largest players in this industry, there are often overseas assignments available.
cons: The work can be routine unto monotony, especially if the employee does not seek and obtain promotions.  Also, career wise, while public accounting is a great place to launch a career, mutual fund accounting can be a dead end for many.

review_title: Cost Saving Company but Good for freshers
pros:
I am working in banking operations team, as a vba developer
No Pressure good work balance
Management support
Opportunity if you have talent and you are multi skilled person
Good HR interactions and free transport facilities  
Good Insurance policy 
Sodexo
cons:
Cost cutting company
Low salary compared to other companies
Tenures are not kept happy through opportunities
Not all but few  managers from particular state are biased beyond limits (i have seen in others case), however i am happy
They give promotions ie from junior to senior without considering the tenure and year of experience, they give seniority for 2 y exp people , one way good one way its not,

review_title: Put in the time now and it will pay off later.
pros: Working at statestreet is an opportunity to gain industry knowledge through exposure to a wide client base.  Servicing client portfolios gives insight into the workings of the financial system.  For those changing industries, some entry level jobs do not require experience in the financial service industry to start.
cons: Everyone does there own thing and little guidance is given until you make a mistake.  The workload can be difficult to start, but once you get the hang of it, it becomes a pretty routine.  The office is busiest near the end of each quarter.  Do your job and be ready to move on when an opportunity presents itself.

job_title: Client Operations Manager, Senior Associate in Kansas City, MO
pros: Flexibility, great benefits, fun people to work with, laid back atmosphere. I would reco.mend to anyone that is wanting to start a career in finance or business.
cons: Too much red tape, slow to change and making decisions. State street could be much more competitive with hiring if they paid more and retained bright people. Their benefits are becoming  less and less each year which has been dissapointing. Not enough peoe to co.ete the work because of the red tape.

review_title: You can find a better job somewhere else
pros:
I started in a rotational/development program so the job experience was pretty good. When you leave the program, they won't give you a raise for any of the skills and experience you worked hard to develop.
- They give you flexible work arrangements.
cons:
-Anything that isn't nailed down to the floor will probably be shipped over to India or Poland at some point.
-You are hired at market rate and then they will give you every excuse in the book about how times are so tough to justify giving little to no increases in compensation. If you want a raise you need to apply outside the company.
-Incredibly high employee turnover. About 25% of the company turns over every year (leaves for greener pastures).
-One year they cut my cash bonus to almost nothing and tried to justify it by giving everyone a week of vacation instead. Thanks, but I need the cash to travel.

review_title: Great Place to Work with Adjusted Expectations
job_title: Accounting/Price Specialist, Associate I in Kansas City, MO
pros: It heavily depends on your background to determine your satisfaction with State Street. The salary is low for experienced applicants for this with recent bachelors degrees. However, for young workers without a degree or others wanting to explore the financial realm, it can be a great fit. It has a mostly laid back culture with plenty of time off (as most financial industry companies do) and adjustable schedules.
cons: Long term, they have grown accustomed to high turnover. This could be good if you are willing to play aggressive and move up, but for those less aggressive you could be stuck in a "dead end" job as everyone around you departs.

pros: I am fortunate to have a good manager who is willing to let me take on tasks which are outside my job description, therefore allowing me to learn more.
cons:
- Severely underpay. They consider themselves - and are - industry leaders, but they certainly underpay their employees.
- Bonuses are merely few hundreds of dollars even after receiving and outstanding rating from your manager.
- High turnover of people who go to competitors because of the pay only to come back a year later because the company will now provide them a competitive package.

pros: I can work from home twice a week (which is great because the pay is abysmal so I save on gas).
cons: Forget the concept of ever having a team that’s staffed. Everything is “lean” aka as cheap as possible; if it can maybe be done in China or India, it’s going to be. American labor is too expensive. Not only that, so is investing in technology. Fund admin is the only profitable part of the business at the moment and yet the entire company has a hiring freeze and the tech looks straight out of the 80s. I’ve worked 60+ hours a week for the past 3 months and yet they preach work/life balance. Upper management does nothing but spew corporate bs line “synergies” and “hubs” and “plans.”

pros: Anyone with decent social skills will do well and if you keep your own standards high, you will do very well. People are friendly and have a wealth of knowledge about their fields.
cons: Bad behaviour isn’t punished and low standards are tolerated. There is a culture of negativity within the organisation which to a degree is self-perpetuating. You need to try and avoid this getting you down.

review_title: Organization is good but people around you make it worst .Lot of micromanagement and pressure from Onsite.
pros: Work from home ,Sodexo additional to your salary , Transportation allowance if your not using cab facility,CSP events.
cons:
They will give work from home but with lot of restrictions and conditions.
Multiple Managers over your head to answer.
Worst part is more meetings and calls ,you hardly find time to work in office.
Making a mountain out of mole Hill...Even small pitty things will be portrayed as a big issue.
They say they are flexible but they do hell lot of micromanagement.
Onsite team will not be aware of adhoc meetings and your team will be dispersed across the world.(You have onsite manager ,off shore manager,Onsite Avp,offshore Avp ) monitoring you and none of them will be in sync and you face troubles explaining how occupied you are.
Lot of time invested in coordinating with your dispersed team rather than work.

review_title: If nothing else works out, this is a decent back up.  Otherwise, stay away.
pros: The benefits package is pretty good, especially the tuition reimbursement program.  If you do stick it out for the long-term, there is some but limited opportunities for career growth.  Overall, a decent place to get into the financial services field.
cons: As has been described by many others, low pay and low respect level are the big downsides.  You don't do any actual finance or accounting, and the job responsibilities are menial at best.  Nobody would enjoy being a fund accountant.

pros: There is ability to work from home and flexible work arrangements.  Depending on the client you work on, you may get decent industry exposure.
cons:
Extremely low salary and historically low annual merit increase/performance bonus because the company is perpetually cutting costs due to "challenging headwinds", and rather than Innovate or go after new opportunities, they choose to offshore, layoff and keep compensation low. 

Senior leadership in the Sacramento office is uninspiring and stagnant.  Promotions are very political and playing golf or fantasy football with VPs seems to further your career more than actual hard work and value to the company and client.  Turnover is very high and the strongest employees do not stick  around long. 

The work is very operational and siloed with little opportunity for decision making. 

Overall the company feels very cheap and does not instill a sense of pride or confidence in the future.

review_title: Good company overall, but management and hiring process needs to be better.
pros: Large company - vast resources, plenty of departments to work for, brand name, many locations and offices around the world. Culture is fairly informal but this will definitely vary by group.
cons: IT/help desk is probably the worst I've encountered. Big company so it's very bureaucratic by nature. Tone from management is always going to have shareholder value in mind - this is overall a good thing but cost cutting can easily lead to unhappiness for employees if done incorrectly/lazily.

pros:
The company is great, massive, always looking for new ways to do things and I learnt a lot.

My team is always busy, its a great place to grow professionally.
cons:
The manager you get makes all the difference. If you have a bad manager in State Street, you are doomed as the system relies heavily on managers for PPR.

Also, the business speak a lot about work/life balance but there is a lot of complain in the business from employees that have had to take maternity leaves as been stagnated and having no progression for years and it feels like they have been purnished for taking time to have children.

pros: You will be working for a fortune 500 company. Its name speaks volume in the banking industry, particulary in Boston, MA. State Street provides great benefits to their employees.
cons: There is alot of in house politics, especially in an entry-level position. Employees are graded upon work performance. However, favoritism does factor in, when it comes to promotion. The salary is below industry average. $32,000 a year is hard to live on in one of the most expensive cities in America. However, most employees do not stick at State Street for too long, some see it as a stepping stone to other opportunities. The ones that do stay are not the creme of the crop.

review_title: Difficult to understand the importance of what you are accomplishing.
pros: Great place to start out of college.  I would suggest working in such a place for a year and getting what you can out of it and then moving on.
cons: The software was way behind the times.  While I was there the Sacramento office converted over to newer* software.  You were able to process funds quicker but it was still like using MS Dos.  Each screen had a several commands corresponding to a number.  You just memorized the numbers and punched at the key board all day.

review_title: Good Opportunity - Not so great managers
job_title: Client Services Associate I in Boston, MA
pros: Room for advancement within SSGA, Friendly work environment, Facilties were good, Some members of the team would go out of their way to help teach new things. If you are liked you will get fast tracked to a senior position if not you have to work a lot harder for promotions.
cons: Pay was on the low side of the industry, Management lacked the ability to deal with team conflicts, definitely some favoritism amoung employees. Very little movement between the broker and bank sides - no sponsorships given for professional designations on the bank side. Hard time to get moved over to the brokerage side even with managements help.

review_title: It's a new setup in India and I am enjoying the work environment. Management is very effective till now.
pros: Work environment, Fancy desk and chair are really very comfortable, food coupons of 1500rs are given by company above salary, Birthday leave on occasion of your birthday
cons: Their hierarchy is very long, start with associate 1, associate 2, emerging Lead, Team Lead, A M, Manager, SR manager.

pros: It is a good company to work for as long as you are in good books with your manager and middle management. Once management starts recognizing your effort and output, this is a great place to be, but with a capital emphasis on ONCE.
cons: Too much politics in middle management and the ratio of managers to developers is disproportional with too many mid level managers per team. Needless to say,under these circumstances, developer efforts usually get in the background and are overshadowed. Very less visibility for one's work if you are just a developer while the actual productive work would be done by them. Least people friendly HR.

review_title: I feel that State Street does not fully recognize and nurture the talent in its employees.
pros:
Good work/life balance, especially being in financial services.
100% 401(K) match-1st 6% of salary
Benefits are good
cons:
Not enough upward mobility
Management is not very competent; they have their heads buried in the sand
Culture doesn't allow for learning or growth. People are trained to be like robots.
Work can get monotonous.

review_title: IT Subject Matter Expertise - gone soon
pros: Excelent work-life balance, depending on manager.  Supportive and kind co-workers.
cons: Continuously looming layoffs with not enough communication from management.  Very Low morale.  Bleak future outlook.

pros: If you have a good team, your days here could be bearable. Great way to learn the business right out of school. Decent benefits.
cons: This company does not care about its employees. Turnover is extremely high and is getting higher as the continue to outsource every possible job they can to save a nickel. I think I could make more money at McDonald's if I worked there full time. At this company your just a robot brought on to complete whatever mundane task you're assigned. I am pretty sure they'll hire anyone. Not even kidding... As long as you breath you're in. Good luck moving up in this organization if you have any skill.

pros: My manager was great. Outside of the work environment, State Street employees are so down-to-earth and overall awesome people.
cons:
Because of the tedious work I could tell that my coworkers hated their jobs. The people on my team were great, but I could tell their morale was low. A year later most of my team had moved on to work at competitor banks. 
My friends who worked at State Street left after 6 months on average because the pay was so atrocious and went onto places such as JP Morgan and Wellington. They could barely scrape by living in Boston with their State Street salary.
HR is incompetent.

job_title: Assistant Vice President in Kansas City, MO
pros: Relaxed atmosphere, good benefits. Flex work program allowing for good work/life balance. Opportunities abound if you're a new grad or have limited experience.
cons: Long-time career not viable. Constant outsourcing and replacement of staff for "cheaper" staff keeps this from being a realistic goal. Upper management puts no loyalty in staff. Constant threat of being replaced keeps moral very low. Little opportunity for growth, especially long -term due to long-term employees always facing outsourcing replacement. Company growth in recent years appears to hinge only on one thing, cost-cutting and replacement of experienced staff - no real corporate growth.

pros: You have a job with a large company.
cons: You are working for a company than is hell-bent on enriching the lives of  its CEO and the small circle around him by off-shoring thousands of American jobs from Boston, North Quincy, Kansas City, Mo, and  Irvine CA. The effects of off-shoring are a lower quality product being delivered to State Street's clients by workers in India, that are im most cases  poorly trained, and half asleep working 8 time zones away.

pros:
Worked in the Dublin office for a  year and a half.
Good facilities (cafeteria, kitchen etc.).
Good place to start out in fund accounting/ career out of college, having State Street on your C.V. is a big plus for future employment.
Work/Life balance can be good, depending on which area you're in. There was a very sociable crowd where I was, always people around to go for a drink on a Friday after work and very often organised nights out with large groups of people.
cons:
Very poor starting salary, doesn't get much better as far as I am aware, based on anecdotal evidence.
My opinion is that State Street do not look after their staff well at all, especially in the Dublin office.
Found management difficult to deal with.

review_title: Great place to start and maybe more!
pros:
Great place to start coming out of University. Easy transition process and a low stress level work for majority of the year.
The training for the first 6 months really help top up on your knowledge and help learn the systems of state street.
Depending on team there is a good social aspect and the canteen is really well subsidised.
cons:
Like all of accountancy positions the work can become repetitive.
High staff turnover so some people you join with will leave.
You don't know where you stand in the company in terms of promotions.. kind of a guessing game.

pros: Great corporate policies regarding balanced work life, culture of inclusiveness, gender equality, community engagement and lessening environmental impact.
cons:
If you're not located in Boston area, there are limited opportunities.  Right now, entire firm has made a huge bet on their strategy to integrate Charles River into a front-to-back solution.  This means all resources are now diverted to Boston area.  If you're not in Boston, you're left out.  If you're in an area that is not involved in this strategy, you're also left out; most likely your budget is cut.
There's been too many waves of layoffs - and it doesn't seem to be ending.
Bad track record of failing to meet strategies and layoffs would be the result.

review_title: Do your research before you join!!
pros: Its a stepping stone in my opinion. If you are a recent graduate its a good way to learn a lot from those who have been there for many years. The environment is very fast paced. Some of the older people working there, I have no idea how they were hired. Frankly they are incompetent. The compensation is much better then Merill but don't stick around with this company for too long.
cons: Lots of strong headed people in the office, people think they are something since they come from Goldman or other major investments banks but just do your work, put your time in and get the hell out.

pros: A good way to gain some exposure to financial services at an entry level.  Large company with wide array of functions, easy to make moves between departments.  Good benefits and flexible work arrangements for people who want to have more time for family/social/personal endeavors.
cons:
The managers and co-workers vary greatly between different groups.  One group I was in had stagnant managers with dissatisfied clients, and was facing continual layoffs; another group I was in encouraged new ideas and was continually getting new business, getting promotions, and getting new hires every couple months.

The industry is moving towards doing more with less, every group feels like it's being stretched thinner and thinner.

pros: State Street offers a variety of a professional development opportunities to expand your skill set and self-leadership abilities to make your job more fulfilling. The work-life balance is exceptional for a company that is so large and in such an old-school business.
cons: The strict hierarchical structure can lead to stagnation and lack of enthusiasm as the power to affect change is not in the hands of some employees. Silos, extended approval chains and ambiguous responsibility can slow down productivity.

job_title: Pricing Analyst II in Boston, MA
pros:
-Big company with decent management, depending on the team you end up on.
-Pushing more towards work/life balance, starting to offer more flexible schedules.
cons:
-Low pay compared to competitors and difficult to move within company.
-Lot of employees with EXTREMELY poor grasp of English makes it difficult to communicate.

review_title: StateStreet is at top position of the finance service industry
pros: StateStreet values talent employees and is willing to train newly graduated students. And it has flex work program to help employees easy balance work and life.
cons: As an individual, it is not easy to understand the whole picture of how StateStreet run its business, and what role each different department plays in the whole picture, as information is always provided  on "need to know" strategics.

review_title: Good company but limited growth potential for middle management. Reward those making less not who make the most impact.
pros: Good brand, good niche in market, allows for forward momentum in early career stages. C suite management has good strategy and plans. Decent benefits. Nice approach for flexibility. Many people are nice and work hard.
cons: Very little growth track once you are a VP, very socialist when it comes to raises for VP and up. More money given to those on lower end of bands - Not to key contributors that align best to the values outlined by the CEO.  Extreme cronyism.

review_title: If you have worked anywhere else this will be worse
pros:
They pay you each month (nowhere near the market rate but they do pay you!)
"Welcome to State Street" seems a nice thing to say but it is the phrase they use to new hires when the new hire questions the ludicrous ways that State Street does things! Translates to "I know its absolutely ridiculous but don't even bother thinking you're going to change anything."
cons:
No strategy. 
Unbelievably status oriented. Don't bother having any ideas about how you could improve things- it's only your boss who can have ideas. And don't try arranging a meeting with someone of a higher "bank grade" or sending them an email. They won't respond. 
Dictatorial 
Culture of presenteeism. You need to be seen to be in the office and for extended hours. It's not about what you deliver.

pros: Flexible arrangements, work from home access, decent number of vacation days, looks good on a resume (great starting point).
cons: Low starting salary (non-negotiable). Long hours (overtime is implied), have to work on most holidays, outdated software. Extremely stressful at times (have to handle many different processes, crucial deadlines, and resolve frequent issues that arrive). Large amount of individuals hired are inexperienced/not educated for positions, while others have been there for years with no true purpose.  There is no true explanation to what you're doing, you have to teach and figure it out yourself. Extremely high rate of turnover due to environment/processes. Consistently hear about jobs being off-shored.

review_title: Strong, safe company, solid work/life ballance, low compenstion.
pros: State Street is a large, stable company that is growing despite difficult economic times. The benefits are very good; the hours and work life balance is excellent in my position. The management team that I work for directly is great.
cons: The salary is quite low. Being a large, tradition corporation, I find myself doing the same things over and over with little strategic input. There are a lot of folks in my area that come in, give their 8 hours, and head home; they do what they have must to get through the day, but there is not an effort to try to improve the normal processes.

review_title: Nice people let down by poor systems, poor communication ethos and parochial beginnings.
pros: A fair employer, good benefits.  Some slightly insecure middle management threatened by talent beneath them.  Good support for off site training.
cons:
