Every minute is billable as born from a law firm - this means recording every hour per code per week.

Mourant struggles with lateral thinkers - the majority of the workforce are not university educated and they struggle when working on transactions with London based alwyers like Linklaters/Freshfields on international deals.  On the job training from Directors on complex deals is non existent. Administrators are taught clients, not skills, so don't realise their worth.

review_title: Very low pay, but nice people
pros:
The people I work with are helpful and friendly. I like all of them.
Learn some financial terms and about mutual funds
Improve Excel and typing skills.
Easy to get hired, regardless of your background.
cons:
I made more money babysitting than doing fund accounting at State Street. The low pay motivates me to take it easy and not work too hard, as I don't want to be taken advantage of by overworking and stressing out for $32k.
 I have 2 other jobs to supplement my fund accounting job so I can live. Most of my coworkers still live with their parents and have pt jobs too.

review_title: Fortune 500 Company with nothing to be proud of
job_title: Bank Loan Specialist in Boston, MA
pros: Good Benefits, Work from home time, Co-Workers are very friendly and young
cons: Terrible management, terrible communication, no organized training, broken promises, no opportunity, low pay, sneaky, they promote based on how long you've been there rather than ability, and  no appreciation the list can go on and on

job_title: Fund Accountant Associate I in Kansas City, MO
pros: As far as the people you work with and how management treats subordinates, it's a great company.  A great company for the community as well.
cons: For me, entry level pay left a great deal to be desired.  Management seemed very disorganized and unprepared for anything out of the ordinary day's routine.  Benefits (especially health) were terrible.  In my case, I commuted 40 miles; it wasn't worth the drive.

job_title: Operations Administrator II in Quincy, MA
pros: It's a good name on the resume to find something else. Great raffels. Will get a lot of experience quickly. The benifits were good before this year. For 2016 they have cut rate insurance with Cigna, whom, have an active class action suit for misrepresentation.
cons: Could write a volmue here on pointless meetings that do not effect real progress, high team-member turnover, low morale, expected overtime every night, No work/life balance, and constant budget cuts that means do more with less people; However, I'll simply write this, the Boston globe recently published in the next 4 years SS forecasts 7,000 additional jobs cut. This will be the environment you walk into...

pros: Flexible work arrangements (work from home, modified hours/schedules). Supportive of internal movement, great training programs for a wide variety of disciplines. Collaborate environment.
cons: So big it is difficult to navigate and find the right contact when needed. Very heavy workload with not enough staffing resources. Moving lots of jobs overseas which is discouraging, since we are in desperate need of resources in Boston.

pros:
The benefits package is extensive, even considering the high deductible health plan.
There are many opportunities throughout the company (as an employee), as it is always trying to revamp and digitize its processes.
cons:
VERY compartmentalized teams.
HIGHLY distributed teams.
I don't see the impact of my work as a developer.
Around 90% of IT are contractors. Leads to less engagement regarding enforcing best practices and improving teams if everyone knows that their time is limited.

review_title: A submarine sinking into a wooden boat
job_title: Senior Associate in Los Angeles, CA
pros:
- a lot of knowledge grasped about equity products, ERP, Bloomberg Terminal
- at market PTO/sick leave/volunteer days
- flex time to work remotely, but this depends on a lot of insider things
cons:
- computer software/hardware is from 2005, and Windows Vista/7 based...
- middle managers working 12 years plus are hypocrites, and don't know what they're doing
- endless outsourcing to India in 2011 (they sourced to PH in 2014 because India performed disturbingly horrid, things became fine until 2018, where India decided 'hey things are looking good, let's bring the business back to India')
- if it's a program not given to India, then State Street will give justification to 'restructure' in Poland.

pros:
-Flexible work arrangements in some business units.
-Big emphasis on macros and infusing technology to reduce manual processing and increase efficiency.
-Co-workers are friendly enough. I guess that's why they invented the bar.
cons:
-Pay is not competitive, and you have little to no bargaining chips because your position is mostly expendable.
-Management has little to no sympathy with the plight of the worker bee.
--You're constantly working (by work, I mean reconciling reports, signing off every page, fussing over the minutia, like proper signature & dates). I'm not a lazy person - the work is just very...dull.
-Tight deadlines. Constantly.

review_title: Good place to start, but not a place for a career
job_title: Fund Accountant Associate II in Kansas City, MO
pros:
*Great place to get some experience on your resume
*Benefits better than average
*On site cafeteria, coffee shop, and fitness center
*Work from home access
*Managers are generally flexible with work hours and personal issues (experience may very upon which team you are on)
cons:
*Abysmal pay (after one promotion and three merit "increases" I still qualify for food stamps)
*Annual layoffs
*Constant outsourcing to India
*Employees generally unmotivated
*Senior Management totally unaware of difficulties in the lower ranks
*High turnover and constant short staffing

review_title: Good for new graduate experience, bad culture for long term career
pros: I worked at State Street for six years and built my resume with them.  I learned a lot of job skills and much of what I know about investment banking.
cons: I did not like the lack of respect given to non-officer positions.  There is really a divide between your supervisor and you.  It is a very arrogant divide where people you come to face to face everyday will not look at you or treat you as if you exist because your salary/position is not at a level to impress him/her.

pros: Good people & friendly culture.  Relatively quick to make decisions and somewhat empowered compared to other large US firms that I've worked for.  I enjoyed my time at State Street.
cons: Very silo'd.  State Street Global Services are effectively an Investor Services Provider.  Buyside clients normally buy a bundle of services.  The sales process is integrated, but that actual operations are fragmented across UK and EMEA region.  They quote "advantage" as a sales pitch (being an integrated provider), but when it comes down to it, there are multiple ops managers and client service teams trying to service your account.  Key timelines also do not show the benefit of an integrated solution.  Why so many MD's and SVPs in Global Services?

pros:
Good if ur manager is good.
Lucky to have got a good manager.Hence ur world may turn within a fortnight.
they pay you good but expect a slave in turn.
no weekend login though.
training plan is good but systems are disaster.
they 10 more activity which they have for system glitches.
You can for a short span of time but not for longer duration for.I,bet very few ppl(read psychophants) can.
cons:
Expats have foul mouth and will use cuss words for you if you go to seek their advice and which they might think they can say just like that.
no hr is there to raise such issues and managers are taking liberty for that.
even they don't have an exit interview while you are leaving the organisation.

review_title: State Street is happy with mediocre performers
pros: This is a great company for non-financial workers to get basic training and experience in financial services. The company can offer opportunities to motivated individuals and is looking to expand outside the US. State Street is not likely to be acquired by another company.
cons:
The employee experience can vary within the company and there are multiple layers of management.
There are many employees who are not motivated and don't take ownership. The fastest way to get a raise is to leave the company. Executives think they deserve the same pay as their investment bank counterparts.

pros: In my group the environment is pretty laid-back; there is no strict time around when you have to come in and when to leave as long as the job is done. The need to work overtime arises fairly rarely. I work in the project environment and there is always an opportunity for the people who want to get ahead to get on a project that would help them advance.
cons: Sometimes I feel like communication suffers. There is not much cohesiveness among peers and many people come in the morning to only get out in the end of the day; not much socializing going on.

review_title: 'Outsourced' was a great show.  Outsourced is not a great working environment
pros: Flexible work schedules and a good work-life balance make the heavy workload a little easier to manage.
cons: Rapid company growth by way of aquiring competitors' assets creates a very unstable work environment.  Outsourcing has become part of the company's culture and is no longer just a way to supplement and add flexibility.  Large scale layoffs on a nearly annual basis contribute to low morale.  Opportunity for advancement is difficult due to bottlenecks at the middle management level.  Salaries, raises and bonuses are not very competitive.  Employee appreciation is virtually non-existent.

review_title: State Street is an ok launching pad, but make sure you do not stay here for longer than 3 years
pros: Young company with a lot of friendly people who you can develop relationships with. Paid overtime for over a 40 hr week. Matching IRA of 5%.
cons: Redundant brainless job. Low pay and low ceiling for pay. If you stay here longer than 3 years your career could be hindered as you are not developing any real transferable skills. My co-workers who had been working here for 5+ years were depressing. They hated their jobs but still went to work every day grumpy and depressed.

pros: None, seriously if you have no other job opportunities or just need some money that should be the only reason you work there.
cons: Leadership does not care about you. They just want the job done. You never really understand what you are doing. You have to scrape at a few nice people still there to help you with anything. The whole company is design to do the bare minimum without the clients getting upset.  Many of the employees who work there are extremely rude and completely unprofessional. Benefits every year get cut. Your bonus is a joke, if you get one... even if the S&P has risen 30% and business is up.

pros: The ability to learn new functions and understand the mutual fund accounting/reporting protocol. Also the chance to better understand the way a company's actions (AKA corporate actions) affect share holder accounts by examining the change to account values based on expected dividends/return on investment.
cons: The deadlines were hard to meet because often the technology would not run properly and management did not know how any other ways of getting the information. Also, management often blamed the employees for software issues.

pros: Plenty of room for growth and development. Many young professionals with adequate credentials, who are available for networking and skills leveraging. Quality of management can be hit or miss depending on the group you work in and can range from exceptional to less than desirable. Work/Life balance is pretty good considering potential work from home days and ample vacation time.
cons: Lower end of compensation within global services. Very difficult to make the transition from global services to global advisors.

pros: Flexibility of work hours, if you are in the right group. Some also allow work-from-home options. Plenty of opportunities for growth. Many different groups within the bank, with the chance to learn something new.
cons: Extreme favoritism runs rampant in a lot of groups, so upward mobility can sometimes be difficult within the same group. Raises have been virtually non-existent, so can be difficult to keep up with cost of living increases.

review_title: Low pay, good experience, bad pay, attain vast knowledge, horrible pay
pros: At State Street you actually work with people that are around the same age group, so with that being said it's quite enjoyable at work cause you have an easier time in building a very good rapport with the coworkers in the department. The knowledge you gain from State Street is actually above average in terms of understanding the concepts in the investment industry.
cons: The salary is way below average, let me say that again, very very low.  In terms of what other people are receiving its quite discouraing because they way the company operates, this would be actually a very very good place to work for IF the pay is actually the average means of salary.

review_title: A good start in financial services industry
pros: You get some experience working with a variety of securities, especially equities, fixed income, and derivatives, most of the people are fun to work with, opportunity for flex scheduling, depending on your business unit, that is if you work an additional 45 minutes every day for the fiscal year, you can get a day off every two weeks.
cons: The compensation is low by industry standards, resulting in higher employee turnover rates. Sometimes there is a lot of pressure to ensure that deadlines are met. There can be times that you may have to work longer hours.

review_title: My talents were not used to their greatest potential.
job_title: Client Relationship Officer in Boston, MA
pros: I loved the work I did for my clients.  The people overall were very nice.  Benefits on the whole were good however State Street discontinued their pension plan.
cons: Salary not competitive with the marketplace.  State Street used to be a welcoming place to work.  People accepted lower salaries in exchange for relative stability.  Due to market turbulence and executive mismanagement State Street no longer offers a nurturing  work environment and instead is squeezing all the work it can from its remaining employees.

pros: Friendly and competent co-workers. Good place to see if a large multinational is a good fit for you.
cons: Event though it's a large company, silos exist between different departments of the same business unit. If you're looking to get into a company for a wide range of opportunities, look elsewhere, as State Street seem to prefer to keep you in your box.  A true lack of transferable skills exist, except if you want to do the same thing over and over again for 20 years.

job_title: Texter / Konzeptioner / Kommunikations- und Strategieberater in Kansas City, MO
pros:
State Street is a great place to work with much better than average benefits. In all the teams I have worked with here management has always been supportive in helping you in your role and in developing ones career. 
The work can be repetive when first starting out but gets more challenging and less repetitive as you gain more experience and move up in the company. Many people on here complain that promotions don't exist but fact is if you show some dedication and are willing to go beyond your job role it is very easy to get promoted.
cons: While the benefits are great the pay is bellow average for the industry.

pros: State Street has been around for a long time.
cons:
- sweatshop working conditions; consultants have it better than fulltime employees. 
- the most incompetent people get promoted to management quickly and easily. They are juvenile and borderline abusive with ample yelling and screaming in meetings. 
- the management does not support, or even appreciate your efforts. There is no room for personal development, and your manager will throw you under the bus at the first opportunity to do so. 
- highly political environment, as there are very few people that can actually get the work done. 
- it is never convenient to take any vacation, and you cannot carry it over or cash it out. 
- when you get sick from being so overworked, they will drive you out of your job. There is a revolving door of people joining and leaving the company.

job_title: Functional Specialist II in Boston, MA
pros: work from home opportunities, work life balance, reasonable hours, manageable workload, large company so lots of opportunities to get involved outside of work
cons: below market pay, very little opportunity for professional growth, too much focus on specialization, lack of interest in professional development of employees

review_title: Not great for the long run
pros: schedule is flexible but that's really about it.
cons:
depending which team you're place in, the work isn't that great. Sometimes they will error you for doing something wrong and won't let you explain why you did what (or they won't consider it "acceptable"). Communication isn't great, they act as if they're great with their communication, telling you to request for time off, if scheduling conflicts come up to let them know, but in turn, they won't let you know if they've approved it. The most they'll really answer to is adding on extra shifts. They'll always ask for extra shifts and they implemented a mandatory Saturday/Sunday shift in my team as well, which isn't great.
Communication with teams at other sites are awful as well, sometimes they don't understand English that well and won't listen/understand what you're saying and just keep insisting what they have to say. It's awful
They say they're all about the culture but I say...where?

review_title: A Slow Moving Giant with a Frustratingly Stubborn Infrastructure
pros: A lot of flexibility with regards to work hours, very structured internship offering tons of networking events, most managers (especially from GE Capital) that I have met are pretty sociable and nice. Great place to get introduced to Financial Services.
cons: Not a very demanding work load. Make sure to go out of your way to find more work. I asked people on other teams and learned a lot. Also reflects positively. Seems like a lot of people want out. The infrastructure of the company reminds me of the first Microsoft Windows operating system, will be the demise of their downfall if not fixed.

pros: very few pros. Good place for people without any ambition
cons:
- Management are more concerned with trying to keep their jobs that getting any decisions made is impossible. Most management have been there for over a decade and have very little idea on current practices or what is going on at the competition. As a result their product knowledge is limited to custody and fund accounting. 
- Poor salary rates for anyone other than EVPs who pay themselves at the expense of the rest of the staff
- Very little chance of advancement. Promotions go to those who don't cause any waves.
- Constant cost cutting however this usually only affects the lower levels of staff with the senior people still making sure they retain their perks.

pros: Great entry level job out of college. A good environment depending on the team you are with. Very accessible, I am in the office 4/5 days because of the working from home option.
cons: You can get lost in the shuffle, and if you do not make it a point to go to your manager it is very easy to not be recognized in daily activity. Sometimes I would go a 1-2 days without talking to anyone face to face. Everything is very email based, not enough communication between teams.

review_title: Light at the end of the tunnel is another train
pros:
- Immediate people are just trying to do their best with the difficult environment
-Work/Life balance
cons:
-Management withholds information
-Hiring freeze in some areas going on for over 1 year. This has held off on any promotions, raises and backfill in positions
-As there is significant moves to a more mobile staff, firm does not subsidize this significant move for the employee

review_title: Valuable Experience, But They Don't Care about Your Hard Work
pros:
It is a big company
Friendly people
It will give your the exposure on custody services
Good benefit
Very nice office building
cons:
Very low salary, no OT paid
Tons of work, average OT hr = 50 hrs per month, work from 7am to 10pm during monthend
Take turns for morning shift without any compensation
Management team earns a lot, but they are not doing their work
Very high turnover rate, therefore 99% employees in FG below age of 40
Poor technology, system always down
Keep hiring cheap labor in India and China
No lay off plan, but they want you to leave by creating a stressful working environment

pros: Some nice, qualified people.  Made some great friends here.  Location is right on public transportation.
cons:
Lots of not so nice, not so qualified people.

Huge egos, zero concept of teamwork, always waiting for the other shoe to drop.  My experience is with IT, but word of mouth says it's everywhere.  

"Transformation" - really?  How many of the purported transformations have failed?  Answer - all of them.

pros:
Flex working.
Good benefits.
Good opportunities to re-locate if that is what you want to do.
cons:
So much driven out of Boston with little understanding or consideration of what happens in Europe.
Information security is driving a disproportionate  amount of work within the business.
Processes are in-flexible, unworkable and destroy any productivity.

review_title: Excellent place to begin a career if you're new to the financial industry.
job_title: Fund Accountant in New York, NY
pros: Excellent place to begin a career if you're new to the financial industry. If you're looking to get into the industry but don't have a strong background, State Street is a good place to get your career launched. The overall level of talent is lower than you'd expect at one of the bigger firms, but they hire capable and friendly people. The culture is fairly laid back, but maintains a professional atmosphere.
cons: Among the lowest pay in the industry, but generally fits the qualification level required. The work itself is quite tedious with low levels of variance. There aren't many opportunities for creativity as the work is quite repetitive

review_title: A good place for a steady Eddie.
pros: The people and the carmarderie at State Street is a huge reason employees stick around at SSC.  Long lasting bonds and friendships are made that can last a lifetime.
cons: The size of the organization makes it difficult to get noticed.  If you are used to receiving promotions and moving up the "corporate ladder" then SSC is not suitable place for you.  The communication as well as most places can be much improved and engage others in decision making.  Everyday you may think you are going to make a difference, but when you sum it up, the only difference makers are at the top.

review_title: Pretty much nuetral, not great and not bad
pros: The benefits are great as well as the retirement 401K plan is pretty good.  I have had positive experiences with my managers within my department.
cons: But as I suspect with many large employers there is a big disconnect between upper level management and the people actually doing the work.  There are way too many levels from the top down that would significantly simplify the organization.

job_title: Fund Accountant, Associate I in New York, NY
pros:
Decent work/life balance. Few overtime hours are required which I'm happy to put in since the pay is not great.
Four weeks vacation if you've been at the company for 3 plus years.
There are career opportunities if you're outgoing and can management's behind.
cons:
No raise, no bonus, horrible performance review system.
IFS perks have quickly but surely dwindled. No cups, no candies in the kitchen. I need my 3pm starburst!!!
Music sites have been banned. I'm pretty sure there have been extensive studies showing music improves employee productivity and morale.
Managers can be nit-picky and annoying. Just put your head down and o your best work to zone out their pettiness.
No annual company party. Pretty pathetic, me thinks.

review_title: Just don't care - You near of reach 50 and are not upper management?  Good Bye
pros: great learning and enjoyed my job.  Benefits were good and pay was pretty good.
cons:
Always afraid of being laid off.
Longevity means nothing.
Obvious age discrimination. 
Good Ole' boy network.

pros: An abundance of smart, hardworking professionals, from whom you can learn a lot about the business. It is a pleasure working with them because they care about what they do and want to be the best at it.
cons: Can be a stressful place to work, lots of moving parts and still some silos (it's better now than it used to be in that regard). Also, the threat being laid off is often on people's minds.

job_title: Account Administrator- Loan Services Unit in Boston, MA
pros: Well known company in a great city, great for entry level.  Most other entry level workers are around the college grad age, so if you are just moving to Boston it is a great place to make new friends.
cons: Pay is terrible, you start at $32,000 a year based on a 36.5 hour work week, and trying to live in Boston on that salary is hard to do when you must pay $1,000+ per month for an apartment in the city.  Rarely do you end up only working 36.5 hours as you are required to work long days and occasional weekends during quarter ends.  You must put in a lot of years before being promoted.

review_title: Great place to gain experience but don't stay too long
pros: The benefits are good and the GA, GM and Securities Finance groups are the most desirable ones to join. Most of the jobs are stable until recently when the company strayed from their principles and ended up with riskier assets (off balance sheet financing, couduits, high yield funds by investing in toxic assets). There is an organized hirearchy which is both good and bad
cons: Internal politics can be too constraining, the structured environment does not encourage quick results and outdated technology is in use for most part.

review_title: Get the Experience and Then Get Out!
pros:
Well-established institution with a 200-year old history
Opportunity to work overseas
Good place to learn basic financial reporting and pricing skills
cons:
Not an intellectually stimulating environment; corporate culture is anti-intellectual, more oriented to sports  (especially golf tournaments and the like)
Quality of middle-management uneven at best
Company doesn't retain the most talented people - they become bored and frustrated
Company balks at paying overtime, despite the heavy work load
Senior management too isolated from the rank and file

job_title: Senior Fund Accountant in Boston, MA
pros: I gues its good to work here if you like empty promises of promotions and raises.  Some groups offer a flexible work schedule so you can be out earlier, so that is good I guess.
cons: Low pay mainly because of the high turnover rate. Work gets very stagnant after a while and you don't seem to learn too much about the industry, only the particular fund(s) you are responsible for.

pros:
-Benefits
-Good place as an Officer to compare your past performance and responsibility and to gauge your ability to continue in mentoring new comers.
cons:
This relates only to the Investors Bank and Trust division, acquired by STT 2007:
- Non-existant leadership
- No focus on the work, only politic practicing
- Runny, red noses everywhere
- Unmotivated staff content on wasting your time
- Locker room feel
- Focus on breaking technology to interrupt the process and, in turn, wasting your time
- Training department is straight out of a PX90 commercial
- Employee morale dampered by politicing
- Coddling by large men better suited, but afraid, of construction

pros: Good benefits package.  However, this does not out way the cons of working here.  Unless you are straight out of college or unemployed I would not recommend.
cons: The pay is probably the worst part.  Entry level positions are paid well below the market average.  Work live balance is increasingly becoming very negative with layoffs and not replacing backfill positions.  When you do get promoted and work here for several years you become a target for layoffs, this bank is not what it used to be.

review_title: Ok as a first job out of college
pros:
-Get to develop on your core skill here (excel, communication, problem solving)
-Get an introduction to the corporate and finance world
-Expand your knowledge of finance. Get to learn the back office activities of finance
cons:
-Bad management (associates know more than the managers above them). Managers think they are god's gift to the world.
-Only company that I know of that doesn't promote the person that know more in the department. 
-Can get stuck working for the same department
-department have no idea what other departments do, even though they work together on a daily bases. 
-Compensation/Salary stinks

review_title: Be prepared for an bumpy, uncomfortable ride
job_title: Client Operations Associate in Toronto, ON
pros:
The benefits - health, dental, volunteer days, etc.
Excellent work location in downtown T.O. - close to everything
Very modern office environment
cons:
Work is very mundane with poor training to get you started
Management (at least in my case) can be absolutely awful. They are there only (ONLY!!!!) to correct your mistakes and point out your flaws if you make a mistake. They do not care one iota about your professional development. 
No overtime pay ( and you will find yourself working many overtime hours for free to finish)

review_title: I enjoy coming into work but would enjoy it more if the salary was higher
job_title: Fund Accountant, Associate I in Sacramento, CA
pros:
Employees here are very laid back and easy to talk to!
Coming into work doesn't actually feel like "work", which is every person's dream! Great culture here.
They promote volunteering & building your network.
They hold classes where you can learn more about finance/accounting as well as how to develop yourself in your career
Supportive executive management
Depending which team you are placed under, promotions can happen yearly or even longer.
cons:
Although I really enjoy doing what I do here, the salary is the one thing that is making me want leave.
Tasks can get repetitive.

pros: good benefits package. starting vacation is 18 business days. workforce is typically young. always something to learn, you will never be bored. lots of employee engagement activities.
cons: salary is not competitive. huge communications problem across teams and with management. it can feel very political at times, especially when promotions are concerned. managers lack leadership training. most of them delegate, but don't know how to lead. it takes a lot of assertiveness (or just knowing the right person) to get stuff done.

pros: The people are great to work with; (at least below upper management level...). You can form lasting relationships and if you work frequently enough with them, you will learn a lot and you know they have your back. Also, compared to some other companies the benefits are really good; health, dental, life insurance, vacation time.
cons: Unfortunately, SSC has a long history of downsizing, building up groups, downsizing again, building up again, etc; as well as outsourcing (which most companies are doing nowadays). Company loyalty is no longer important, and so they are losing their most knowledgeable resources. Also, the stress can be very high in some groups. This is not unusual given the industry but there is no compensation for long hours, and weekend work.

job_title: Accounting/Pricing Specialist in Kansas City, MO
pros: Benefits start the first day of the month after you start. 3 weeks of vacation (prorated based off of start date), fed holidays off, cheap insurance, advancement opportunities. Entry level employees pay was increased to compete with market.
cons: Company can spend millions on upgrades but give employees penny raises. Sending jobs oversees paying them less than a tenth of what they pay an entry associate here. Pay from entry to 200 not much of an increase.

pros: Some really great people work here.
cons: The good managers have their hands tied.  They can't give the review status, raise, and bonus they think the people deserve.  Quite a few departments are told to give the majority if not all of their people average (3's) on their reviews.  This holds back transfers, raise amounts and bonus amounts.  The sad part is that every division has a different set of rules.

review_title: Interesting but pay is too low
job_title: OTC Derivatives Specialist in Irvine, CA
pros: Family friendly, management respects employees' personal time.   Company is comitted to global philanthropy - thoroughly enjoyed participating in these events.  Company provides 2 paid days off to volunteer in your community.    This is a  great place for a newly minted college grad.  Young, friendly, fun employees.
cons: Pay is too low.    There are strict limits on pay increases even if substantial increase in responsibility.  Company is too focused on cutting costs.  High turnover, disgruntled employees.

review_title: Good place to gain experience or retire!
pros: Good entry level place to get experience. Good place to retire if you have no ambition and don't care about career growth.
cons:
Salary increases are pathetic. No opportunities for growth. Management is always looking to give you a rating of 3 or less so they can avoid paying you a decent compensation increase. If you are liked by your manager, you get flexible work at home. If you not liked by management, you have to come to work.
Like to outsource to India, then hire the FTE's back as temp assignments at lower pay and no benefits when outsourcing fails! Pathetic...

pros: Benefits are pretty good, but the company recently decreased the matching compensation for retirement.  When completing benefit options, the company intentionally defaults to the more expensive options for an employee, i.e. the employee smokes, thus increasing their health care costs.
cons: Stagnant business model with too many consultants running the show.  The compensation for different divisions creates competition and does not foster a collaborative business.  Senior management is unethical and HR is just a function in name.  Stay away from this place at all costs.

review_title: Great place to launch a career, salary makes it very hard to stay long term
pros:
Good benefits
Simple job functions, don't need to think much after learning processes
Relatively little job stress
Friendly work environment
Solid resume builder
Will hire people with little work experience
CEO and Senior Vice President conduct quarterly "Town Hall" style meetings where various issues within the company at the corporate and office levels are discussed
cons:
Job is very repetitive 
Very low salary for the industry, even up to the Officer level
Relatively easy to get complacent within the company

pros: Good company culture, onsite gym & cafeteria, work-life balance, PTO, 401k match.
cons: Compensation is well below average.  Starting salaries are very low and promotions are capped at a certain percentage.  This makes it impossible for your salary to ever catch up to "market value".  State Street on the resume can make it difficult to gain fair value from potential employers since most know how low they pay.  It is also very difficult to move from operations to other functions.  KC office is looked at as the little brother compared to Boston office.

review_title: Great coworkers, decreasing value placed on healthy work/life balance from management.
pros: Excellent back office experience. Many wonderful coworkers. Knowledge gained and exposure to industry was very valuable.
cons: "Global Competitiveness" is a clever way of saying they are looking for the cheapest possible way to business, regardless of poorly our Asian, Indian, and other outsourcing partnerships treated its employees. "Professional Development" often meant being required to take on more work, without additional compensation. For the six years I was employed,  four of those years I was told that management couldn't afford raises and promotions, and I should be thankful just to have a job.

review_title: You learn a lot on your own
pros:
Free for all environment-that's the best way I can explain it. For someone who had no prior leadership skills or needed to develop initiative skills and problem-solving then it's beneficial. 

I had no prior experience in fund accounting and learned a great deal.

Opportunity to move up fast if you dig their culture
cons:
Lack of procedures
No team morale/spirit
Management lack of leadership skills
Hard to grasp the overall values or culture of the company
Long Long long hours
Lack of engagement activities for staff
Pay is NOT competitive at ALL!

pros: The training was very poor and when you ask questions , you were made to feel stupid. Management style of management is ‘command & control and lacked soft skills.They have a very high turnover of staff.The managamnet had zero managment skills.
cons: This is one of the worst companies I have ever worked for, the Kilkenny branch fails to embrace multi-cultural environment, very bad indication for a Multinational company.

pros: State Street strives for performance excellence at both the individual and organizational level. The investment themake in the personal and professional development of their people is what leads to the company's success. By also investing in the development of exciting and new technology, employees are equipped to succeed in offering clients a complete range of investment products and services.
cons: There is limited room for advancement. Employees are not well compensated- considering the requirements for the position. It should be noted that State Street do over compensates its Officer Level Employees and does nothing to reward the non officer level employees- small raises, small bonuses and long hours.

review_title: Great Entry-Level, Not So Great Anything Else
pros: There is quite a bit of stability, the benefits are great, a good reputation.  If you are looking for somewhere to explore a field this is your place.  If you're looking to plant a flag, you might want to sail a little further.
cons: There is fairly little upward mobility under 4 years.  The work can be repetitive at times (especially after you master whatever you're doing), and you don't get the investment training you would expect applying here unless you take alot of proactive measures.  The pay is nominal as well.

job_title: Fund Accountant, Associate I in Boston, MA
pros: lots of down time on the floor, you can do quite a few personal things depending on which group you are in. vacation time is very flexible, mostly because others can cover for you easily, which also means you will have to cover for others if they are on vacation, or quit...
cons: pay is way too low comparing to other firms, BNY mellon pays almost 30% higher, it is impossible for STT to retain talents in fund accounting, though it doesnt really matter now since they are outsourcing most of the fund accounting to India.

review_title: Good Entry-Level job... if all your other options don't work out.
job_title: Fund Accountant in Kansas City, MO
pros: Good Entry-Level Job, Resume builder (seems other accounting/finance companies hire from State Street), three weeks of vacation to start off
cons: Low Pay for a College degree, as the economy has come back the company is having a hard time finding/keeping good talent, Huge turnover and slow to rehire which causes stress on team members that stay around, Hard to see the full picture of what your repetitive tasks are accomplishing, Outsourcing jobs to India

pros: People are great, lots of opportunity to expand knowledge and to advance up/around the organization.  Opportunities to work from home or in one of the other offices located in the area when needed.  Training is available via online courses, webinars, onsite.
cons: Expect to work a lot - nights/weekends.  Senior management disconnected from the front line issues.  Organization too large and bureaucratic to adapt to changes or effectively address issues.

pros: As an intern, it was a great environment with a lot of support from my manager in finding ways to take on projects and have an impact. Work had real value, and the compensation was great.
cons: The work atmosphere is very muted - people enjoy their job functions but dislike the corporate environment. Everyone is highly cynical, since offices are regularly moved and staffing levels undergo frequent, dramatic shifts (both up- and downsizing). On a base level, everyone is happy with their coworkers and immediate supervisors, but nobody has faith in higher-level executives or the decisions they make.

pros: Ability to work from home is appreciated. Staff are usually friendly and work well together. Employee appreciation BBQ every summer.
cons: Despite work from home, long hours prevents a work/life balance. There is no loyalty to employees and management try to draw blood from stone. Always working on public holidays.

review_title: If you're looking for something 9-5 with anemic growth prospects & a stagnant salary, only then you should work here.
job_title: Investment Manager Representative in Toronto, ON
pros:
Very friendly colleagues, and very amicable.
Opportunities to rotate within the company.
Very convenient hours, typical 9-5.
Very easy learning curve and once you understand the work it's a walk in the park.
A job is a job!
cons:
Very low compensation compared to a similar role at other firms, extremely low bonus.
Back office work, and transition to front office can be somewhat difficult.
Not a lot to learn here after you've learned how to work here.
Extremely repetitive work, can be mind numbing sometimes.

pros: None that I can think of. The benefits such as the matching program are nice, but compensation is one of the industry's lowest, so doesn't do much in that sense.
cons: Poor compensation, mundane work. Not a lot of experience gained here is transferable  to other companies and there is a very, very, gradual learning curve. Not many people that work here are happy with their jobs from what I have seen and heard, but they are nice co-workers. A lot of lay-offs.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in South Boston, MA
pros: Flexibility- working from home as needed.  There are good people who work there and collegial environment.
cons: Overall company is not run well. Problematic group think. Poor career opportunities, lack of mobility, progression, and monetary awards for current employees. You need to come from the outside to get any sort of meaningful salary increase. Bonus payouts has constricted over time as well as benefits while costs go up.  Negative environment. Everyone feels compressed and overworked.

pros: Gym inside my building was nice. Also pretty good lunch food.
cons: Im writing this review for people out of college like I was looking for a job. State Street will hire anyone. The pay is horrible when compared to others in the industry, the management does not care about their employees mostly because they dont have enough time to be, the upper management is clueless and instead of innovating and treating their employees right to create profits they are laying people off and sending jobs to India to save money for their shareholders. IF YOU HAVE ANY OTHER OPTION DO NOT JOIN STATE STREET.

pros: State street has identified a good process to take it to the future. It needs to build a plan for getting this in place and follow through on it.
cons: State street is currently working on a restructuring which has overly complicated the work and created minimums of 8+ hour work weeks forcing employees to work seven days a week and holidays. It appears that either Senior Management is fostering this work environment or unaware of what is going on below them. In either case it has created a company wide moral problem and high anxiety/stress on the employees that is unsustainable.  The long hours with no time off is the company culture that appears to be fostered by management that needs to be addressed by all senior management.

review_title: Referral money making using loopholes in HR system
pros: Great company working hard to contain spend but few bad apples are spoiling the strategy at Bangalore center.
cons:
Few of the  AVP/Sr. Managers are making referral money by referring their own candidates for their own process and splitting the referral money among them-self. 

Bringing the talent just to make money doesn't help the organization to perform better. As each and every one needs to contribute towards business growth by keep their personal agenda(money) out of  equation.

review_title: It was OK, but they have no sense of where they are going
job_title: IT Systems Administrative in Quincy, MA
pros: The Benefits are very good. You are given a fair amount of autonomy. They tend to spend on technology, so you always will work with some of the best tools.
cons: The management seems to be somewhat confused about the direction that they should be going. There is no clear mission. The Upper Management are remote, if not uncaring.

review_title: A great place to start and get some experience right out of school.
job_title: Fund Accountant, Associate I in Boston, MA
pros: This is a big company and the entry-level positions are quite stable. They have a great training program that gives you some insight as to what you will be doing on a daily basis. The training continues once you join the team you work for. As with any job, you continue to learn every day on the job and assume more responsibilities as you move forward.
cons: Unfortunately, it is tough to move up in this company. The best chance is to work for a year and transfer to a different team. Upward mobility is limited within your team. The salary is quite low, but it is something to work with.

job_title: Software Development Manager in New York, NY
pros: Work life ratio great. 4 weeks day 1, work from home
cons:
IBM outsource deal for systems...cannot get much done anymore.
Most development work is off-shore or being pushed off.
Upper mgt Ail CTO and company really have no clue how to run an organization and are looking only to the next fiscal quarter to get their bonus.

review_title: State Street is a performance based company that promotes the hardest workers
pros: The best part of working for State Street is the managers are almost always people who not only excel at their job but are excellent with people skills. They try to get the most out of all of the talent that they have, by being accommodating to their employees.
cons: The biggest con for State Street is that they do not have competitive salaries. The rest of the industry pays not just better, but generally much better than State Street.

pros: The flexibility of being able to work from home if needed is nice. Generally nice people. A lot of activities you can get involved in if you want
cons:
Salary is very very low, especially if you live in a place like Boston with high cost of living. Somehow they have not increased their entry level salary from 32k for years 
Can get very busy and stressful 
A lot of employee turnover, you are just a cog in the machine

job_title: Assistant Vice President in Boston, MA
pros: Chance to learn new technologies, strategies, and make new connections is a big plus.  The company offers chances to experience different roles in the investment world.
cons:
The company's main concern is profitability and the shareholder..
Employees are reminded they are expendable every time the company goes through a new round of layoffs.  Everything is about making the 'numbers' - whatever happened to loyalty and being proud about going to work - now it seems more about meeting performance indicators at all costs, quantity versus quality...

pros:
Laid back culture 
Depending on your department the flexibility is good, along with a decent work from home option.
Good number of smart talented people 
Benefits are decent, offering 4wks of vacation after your first year at the company.
cons:
It’s a great company to start at but if you’re looking for growth this is not the place...
Pay is a bit lower than the standards but they find a way to do that due to OT..
Bonuses will remain low even if u did a fantastic job, senior management may be different
The company is a bit unorganize as far as training

review_title: Solid Company with room for improvement, which is good
pros: Training is abundant.  Support for education and carreer development is good.  Stability of job and exposure across teams is one of the more important aspects of my satisfaction
cons: Teams are too siloed, which can limit cross team/ business unit collaboration.  Pay is not excellent and advancement is tough... I have been told in the past that I deserved a promotion but there were no "spots" available...

job_title: Fund Accounting Manager in Boston, MA
pros: State Street is a recognizable name to put on your resume and it will definitely give you a good experience in the field of your choice. As far as I know, State Street is one of the best technologically equipped companies in the industry. Paid vacation is sufficient. People are nice.
cons: Based on the information that I have from other places and from recruiters, other companies in the industry pay much more money for the same positions. I would expect State Street to offset lower salary with covering insurance benefits 100%, but they don't. As within any big company, your voice might not be heard by Seniors.

review_title: If you have the chance go for it, I am pretty sure is a good platform to start your career.
job_title: Investment Operations Analyst in Boston, MA
pros: Vice president focus on real leadership creating an open communication environment, focus on people needs and trainning. Job environment is great and colleges are always able to help.
cons: Some of the processes are not really computerized and a manual process is required. As any other work, once you master the operations it becomes tedious, but you have to manage to learn things from other areas.

pros: they match 100% to your 401K, the name of State Street has prestige to it, tuitiion reimbursement,State Street is a great company if you work in the right department.
cons: lack of feedback in management, currently there is a freeze with promotions and compensation

review_title: State Street as a company is great... the office middle management needs extreme work in people management/communication
pros: Young and aspiring professionals/peers, casual dress code, supportive director, great people to work with, extremely diverse, emphasis on social responsibility and sustainability. Many office events i.e. July BBQ, Cinco de Mayo, Thanksgiving, Christmas, etc.
cons: Work can get dull and repetitive. Middle management needs more training on people skills and leadership skills. Mandatory overtime in the beginning of the month (month end)

job_title: Senior Associate in Frankfurt am Main
pros:
- Young Teams
- challenging Environment 
- great opportunity to growth & develop if you're willing to deliver
- great senior management offering opportunities, handing over responsibilities & supporting where they can (may differ of course)
In
- international ! (Read a very negative comment before with regards to this' don't know where you come from - maybe you should cross the boarder & see the world before you talk about "internationally"
cons: - lots of talking about travel budget, in fact travel budget doesn't exist for low level employees (up to AVP)

job_title: Client Operations Associate II in Kansas City, MO
pros: They hire straight out of college which is nice, and provide some amount of experience in the finance world
cons: they absolutely detest giving overtime so good luck making more than 38k. they will work you into the ground during those 8 hours a day, and then don't support the CFA or anything other than an MBA. Very, very cheap place, and the experience you get is okay at best and worthless at worst.

pros:
1) New Setup. Growth and Opportunities. 
It is how a professional will take the new setup stage to boost his career. State Street never had a captive presence or a mainstream presence like JP Morgan or Bank of New York. So a big international brand to be associated with in Mumbai. Anyone looking for a custodian exposure can be a part of this co.

2) Pay hikes (while switching from old co to State Street) is good as this is a new setup (Please remember as a captive gets older all of this diminishes with time (Quote : JPMC)

3) Pick up and drop facilities till BKC. As shifts are most irregular pick up and drop facilities for all employees
cons:
1) Work Culture
Mostly everyone in the top management and managerial levels are ex Syntel. So its obviously a Syntel driven culture. Hence , the "third party work culture" is dominant. People coming over from client side or custodian side will definitely feel a controlled atmosphere as this is how third party cos like Syntel function.   
The work culture is a mixed culture of Boston (again controlled supervision and lack of employee freedom) and Syntel (Mumbai) due to the trainers from Boston and the majority of ex-Syntel. Hence , everyone who has left Syntel due to work culture issues should not look forward to come here.

2) Work life balance
There is no work life balance from Associate level to the VP level. Irregular hours should be compensated with work life balance and leaves. But there are no compulsion leave policies or India off policies within the office (HR lacks experience and has a laidback attitude)

3) Salary and Performance Hikes
For the work pressure and irregular hours working , the pay hikes or performance hikes are not in proportion

4) HR issues
Again is this is a new setup we can discount most factors , but a dynamic HR team always has solutions. Out here the HR team organises events and stuff but mostly core HR operational issues are often disregarded in order to make way for employee friend initiatives and fun activities. Dynamic individuals are needed in HR / Payroll dept to help employees. 

4) No cafeteria
I would not have put in this point keeping in fact the new setup. But if you are putting up a project in BKC are you not aware of how stern MMRDA is and how difficult it can be for employees to get regular snacks and food items. Had this been a project in Mindspace or Nirlon , a non cafeteria office would have worked. 
Guess proper project planning was not made into this rather a big name BKC tower was given more priority.

review_title: I still like it here ... but hope for some things to improve
pros:
* Good vacations / sick-day policy etc.
* Generally good managers
* Like with any big company, tons of room to move around internally
cons:
* Health Insurance switched to High Deductible Plans
* Used to be stable, but lots of people let go over the last 5+ years
* Hierarchical / Bureaucratic culture.
* Outsourcing to *** has really deteriorated service levels. It should not be this far behind in this day and age especially with all the talk about Digitization et al. Someone needs to ask the question, can we have the same service levels for our clients that *** provides for us?

job_title: Custody Fund Accountant in Boston, MA
pros: It's fairly easy to get a job if you know someone working there, it's right in the middle of Boston and T-accessible, the benefits are decent, and the job itself is pretty straightforward.
cons: Some workgroups are extremely cliquely and promote a "frat boy" atmosphere, the work is based solely on routine (they don't explain what your funds are or why they're recorded in a certain manner) and it's hard to be promoted without playing office politics.  The pay was low, even for entry-level work.

pros: State Street is a great organization to join out of college, providing much needed exposure to a corporate setting.  They have an impressive array of technology and a user friendly in-house operating system.  The benefits are solid with ample vacation time.
cons: There is very little room for advancement.  Office politics play a pivotable role in advancing.  Hard work is not rewarded, as management's goal seems to be keeping that person in their current position to make their own work easier. The day to day is very redundant which hinders career development.

pros: very friendly staff depending on your team. excellent benefits, dental, pension, flex hours and work from home, pays for your courses, CFA included. sports reimbursement too.
cons: low starting salary but made up for with the 1.5xOT hrs for anything over 40 a week, and 2xOT for anything over 50 assuming you dont mind doing the ot, but heck, if you get the work from home to do the OT, why not.

review_title: Not a company for Talented  employee
pros: Could not  find one good reason to work for this company despite thinking it  over several times
cons: Highly bureaucratic,  talent is not recognised, you need to suck up to your boss and other people with power to get promoted. Highly insecure coworkers and managers. And  you will find many narcissist people who manipulate to get ahead. It has a very toxic culture and  you end up feeling under valued every single day.  Ethics is spoken quite a bit, but there is high levels of unfair treatment and discrimination happening  across the organisation.

review_title: Very boring job with un-ambitious co-workers.
pros: Work is an absolute no-brainer. Just show up and be an excel monkey.  Very easy if you want to surf the web or kill time.  If you are looking for a work environment that requires no effort then this is the place for you.  Co-workers are dull and just as bored as you.
cons: very boring.  People have very little ambition.  There is a lot of bureaucratic nonsense.  Managers were very unhelpful and were extremely obvious when playing favorites. Work is very monotonous.  While there may be upward mobility, it is to equally boring dead end jobs.

review_title: Old Company with strong opportunities to get your feet wet in the industry.
pros: Strong capabilities and a large scope of products this is a good place to get your feet wet in the industry. Pretty flat organizational structure always alot of opportunity for horizontal mobility.
cons: The decision to become a "lifer" should be made quickly. People stay at this company for years. There is also a TON of red tape that prevents anything from being done at anything more than a grinding pace.

pros: If you're looking for experience, State Street offers courses to improve ones skills and provides educational assistance.
cons: You can be overwhelmed if insufficient training is provided. Some operational teams may not have the time to properly train new employees. A "lean" model does not necessarily work here. Cost cutting programs when morale is already down does not translate to a bright future.

review_title: Fantastic development, less than steller rewards
pros:
Fantastic training and development - I walked in the door straight out of college with very little to no experience of the funds industry. This only applies to full time staff however. Contract works and interns, please see Cons below.

Not applicable to every office, but the people in my immediate team were very nice and friendly. Would count some of them as friends. However, once i became privvy to management meetings, I noticed what is said on the floor and what is said in meetings is very different.

Flexible - I was allowed flexible working hours and the option to work from home when required.

Knowledge - some of the more senior people in the team are industry leaders and a great source of knowledge (but see cons for more info)

Opportunities - pros and cons - very easy to progress through the first few levels (A1, A2, Senior Associate) but see Cons for progressing further than that.
cons:
Knowledge - while I stated above that the VPs and above are very knowledgable, they are not very approachable and you'll be lucky to get any response on a query to them.

Salary - not good. Lower end of the market. When negotiating for a payrise, I was told "this is the best we can do, you're lucky to get this as we don't usually go this high". I interviewed elsewhere, got an offer, and then all of a sudden they were able to match the offer from elsewhere. Go figure.

Bonuses - 5% of salary unless you're senior management. Compared to 10-20% elsewhere.

Culture changing - With workloads increasing, the focus has been on getting interns in to keep up with backlogs. I have been invovled in meetings where, upon discussing incoming interns, it was said "we'll just stick them in a corner doing X while they're here - no point training them up on everything if they're going to leave." Horrible attitude.

Opportunities - while progressing through junior levels is very quick (if you're up to the job), progressing beyond that is a no-no unless you're prepared to play office politics. Doesn't apply to me as I've not been here long enough, but I've seen colleagues who have been here for years who are competent, approachable and great leaders be overlooked for those who are pals with senior management, or those who just happen to shout louder.

The disconnect between teams leaders and senior management is enormous. Senior Management have no idea what's going on on the floor. Ridiculous workloads, staff shortage, people at breaking point.... and their solution is "power through".

Morale - the cons have gotten to morale and the atmosphere has now plummetted. I shudder to think what's around the corner.

pros:
Good work/life balance.
Competitive base salary and Merit based yearly bonus structure.
Generous maternity/paternity leave and vacation for higher levels.
cons:
Highly bureaucratic and strict adherence to hierarchy.
Not the place if you are somebody who thinks out of the box and want to do things differently as there are process hurdles.
Attitude among folks is to get the operational system issues working and get by somehow rather than attacking the core of the issue and devising ways to apply a permanent fix which obviously requires some lateral thinking and more often than not, time pressure to deliver comes in the way.
Be nice and visible and you will be rewarded well irrespective of the quality of work.

pros: Great Benefits. Work-life balance. Giving back to the community is encouraged with minimum requirement of 18 volunteer hours yearly. Big on investing in employees by training, education, and allowing for needed time off, etc. Great job for first time out of school. Makes for a good beginner job.
cons: Lower wages than other companies in the industry. Some groups are slower in advancement. Turn over can be a bit high because of lack of pay and reduced promotions. Tends to be longer hours than promised. Expectation to do work of higher title than what your current title is.

review_title: Think twice about joining in US
pros:
-WFH often available 
-Benefits, vaca and leave policies are good
-401k match was upped to 5%
cons:
-Heavy workload/poor morale trying to prop up quality and meeting deadlines from so-so performance of India/other overseas teams
-Low or no raises, bonuses
-Ongoing layoffs to slash “high cost” workforce (mid to lower level jobs) globally, mostly in US, in favor of cheap labor in India, Poland, China

review_title: Good first job, but dont stay too long
pros: For those working in Boston (The down town crossing location) Work is easy and you have plenty of time free to explore Boston during the work day.  The job can be done in a few hours each day, giving you time to check out the ladies tanning in Boston common and public garden or go shopping.  Despite construction, there is still a Macys, borders, H & M, CD store, and discount shops.  It is also easy to get to via the T or commuter rail, no matter where you live.
cons: The pay is horrible and you are very limited with what you can do

pros:
this review is for SSGA, Canada:

1) nice office but mediocre pay compared to the SSGA staff in boston
2) the employee culture in SSgA canada is decent.
cons:
1) too many VPs within a department. This can cause 'too many cooks spoils the soup' situation. VP is like another word for Managers in SSGA
2) If you are not into analytics or portfolio management in canada, there are very limited growth for SSgA canada as most of the positions are located in boston

pros:
Work From Home arrangements
Career advancement opportunities
Promoting from within
Benefit package (excluding compensation) is above average
cons:
Email.  Email.  Email.  Everyone receives over 200 a day and it never stops.  Pick up the phone already.

In today's economy it's a CYA environment.  This starts from the Sr Mgt; let's worry less about placing blame and institute appropriate controls instead.

Although the notion of cost cutting is impressive, cutting costs by offshoring activities is going to come back to haunt State Street.  The level of service provided by State Street's JV is sub par at best.

review_title: Nice people, yet most are not very competent due to overtime incentive and low base salary.
pros: The pros of working at State Street Global Services are really on the people and the culture. Most of them are very nice. They also let you work at your own pace as long you don't take way too much time, and they do pay 1.5 overtime, which is a big plus.
cons: Because of the low base salary and overtime incentives, some employees drag it out. This results in less competent groups of people. In turn, you might have to learn with people who don't really know their stuff and who are afraid to ask questions or to be asked questions.

review_title: State Street used to be good-very good company overall.
job_title: Assistant Vice President in Boston, MA
pros:
Provided the opportunity to move around and work in different areas which broadened the knowledge of how the company operates.
Work-life balance scheduling was great.
Volunteer program was very respectable.
cons:
Once in the company, merit increases were fairly small. Only way to get bigger pay is to go outside and then move back. 
Promotions are based on a "queue" system instead of just good old "he/she deserves a promotion and will get it".

pros:
It is a very good place to start your career as you get to learn and network with many other fresh grads.

If you are willing to stay and do your time, you will surely be promoted to senior roles within your team. Managers and peers are nice people and nice to work with. Management is approachable.


Company has good benefits and is looking to improve work/life balance for employees.
cons:
Long hours coupled with low compensation = high turnover. 

When I worked at State Street, overtime was a common occurrence which lead to a very bad work/life balance as the hours were already weird enough, starting at 10am and having the day end at 7pm (supposedly).

pros: State Street has a deep dedication to technology and being one of the industry's leading provider of services. Being a part of a fast-paced, accurate and dedicated team is something any young employee wants. Finding it here, at a company who, despite popular belief, is quite dedicated to it's employees, was such a welcome change from previous positions I had held.
cons: At times upper-management can be "set-in-their-ways" and slow to implement suggestions from lower-level colleagues. However, that depends on your manager.

review_title: Office Politics is an Actual Thing
job_title: Client Service Specialist in Sacramento, CA
pros:
- good entry level experience: if you put effort into the work and try to learn what you are actually doing, you will see the results
- 401K matching 5% after one year of working
cons: - Upper management, often, does not know what their role entitles; they are mentors and teachers, not someone to be scared of to ask questions. Some of them make you feel so dumb, and its on knowledge that is VERY State Street specific

pros:
Good internal mobility
Can get foot on the ladder in finance
Paid Overtime somewhat makes up for lower pay
Social environment and the ability to meet some friendly sociable people
Some very skilled managers who care about their staff and manage their team effectively
cons:
Poor pay and bonus compared with other banks
Poor management style
Bad, outdated computer systems (constant daily systems issues)
Lack of support and appropriate training , especially for new starters
New starters of all levels not provided with thorough or proper training on internal systems
Strong blame culture, where no one wants to take responsibility for their mistakes (poor accountability internally and externally with clients)

review_title: Not a place that pays enough to live in this state.
pros:
Decent benefits package.
100% 401k matching up to 6% of salary (option of regular 401k, Roth 401k, or some combination of both).
Can be fun place to work (thanks to co-workers).
cons:
Salaries very low and stagnant for the past 2+ years.
Constant layoffs.
The 2 cons listed above lead to very low morale lately.
Hours increased to 40 hours per week but they still pay at the same rate as 36.25 hours.
Management doesn't practice what they preach.
Poor communication from management.
Not much opportunity for advancement.

review_title: Not what it used to be
pros: Good place to get a foot in the door.  It's hard now to learn more then one task now because of the center's of excellence.  When you join a group you basically learn how to do only one thing.  As a fund accountant it used to be you were in charge of accounting and custody.  Now you are only in charge of accounting.
cons: Outsourcing of work is the priority right now.  From what I understand the whole fund administration department is being outsourced.  Compliance, Client Operations, Financial reporting etc.  There is no room for growth.  Layoffs are happening constantly

job_title: Operations Manager in Kansas City, MO
pros: Many good people and interesting work. The company is fortunate to have a wide-moat because if the barriers to entry weren't so great this company would be out of business by now due to poor leadership.
cons: limited advancement opportunities once you move past the first few layers of the organization resulting in high turnover.  Many of the best leaders I have worked with in the organization have been passed over for advancement because they don't have the "right" connections.  Employees are consistently instructed to manage their own careers, but then told where and what they will be doing as the organization continues to fumble through change after change.  Very Boston centric.  Head count to work load, opportunities for advancement and pay differences are skeewed in favor of our Boston counterparts.

review_title: Assistant Vice President / Sr Software Engineer
pros: Flexible Hours.  Some limited work from home options.  Better than average health benefits.
cons:
No mobility within the company.  Most people work on the same project for years at a time.  All new positions are filled with contractors from an outsourcing company.

No initiatives to use new technologies.  

Low pay and horrible bonus structure.  When hired they tell you that your bonus is part of your salary but when it comes time to hand out bonuses they say they're discretional.

Really low morale.

Incompetent middle managers who've only been promoted because of tenure.

review_title: Decent place to start out if you're desperate.
pros: Quick to hire. Flexible work arrangements depending on your manager. Getting fired takes skill. Only about 45 minutes of actual work on an average day if you know what you're doing. Most of the annoying, non-critical security controls can be easily crippled/disabled.
cons: Pathetic pay (33,800). Prolific turnover. Wide spread complacency and general incompetence. Internal mobility very limited and based on time not performance. No incentive to perform more than required. Sporadic workload.

job_title: Assistant Vice President Project MAnager in Boston, MA
pros: Generous vacation, very flexible WFH arrangements, casual dress, decent health and 401k benefits, industry name recognition, internal mobility.
cons:
Poor bonuses, deferred cash/stock bonuses over 4 years if you're VP or above, little to no annual merit increases. Very large company causing lots of red tape and pockets of terrible culture, lots of lifers who've never worked anywhere else and have a warped sense of reality and importance. Not a meritocracy, everything is seniority based. 
Worst of all: poor poor culture of condescending attitudes towards one another. Backstabbing, throwing people under the bus, yelling, and swearing common in meetings and conf calls.

review_title: Long term economic concerns, but good values, honest people
pros: It's a consistent job. You always basically know what you're about to do, and you get to develop a sense of mastery
cons: It's repetitive, it's difficult to move to other parts of the organization, and automation is an existential threat at all times.

pros:
Diverse environment.  Lots of free trainigs.  Good benefits. Trusting bosses.

I got employed in another company after State Street, and I would say State Street is more high tech than other companies that are claiming their system is state of the art.  I've heard the same comment from another friend who worked for other big banks but they're just not as high tech as State Street.
cons: I think the pay is low.  They keep on laying off people and asks employees for ways to make the job more efficient and once we come up of an efficient way to streamline work, they lay off people or never hire anybody to fill in a position.

review_title: Client Operations - Get experience then move on
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Kansas City, MO
pros: Vacation time, good group of co-workers, managers who genuinely cared about advancement
cons:
Mass offshoring. Teams would be created, then a month later, the associates on the new team would be tasked with training offices in India with their new responsibilities. I do not think this office will be in Kansas City much longer. 
Upper levels of management are beyond disconnected from reality. Continuous IT “improvement” on outdated computers would cause slowdowns and crashes. IT group was poor and very unprofessional. Lots of employees who were condescending and outright rude when seeking assistance with tasks. Opportunities would only go to those who knelt at the altar of the EVP

job_title: Fund Administration Officer in Kansas City, MO
pros:
Great benefits of health insurance and vacation 
Use to be solid opportunities for advancement and growth
cons:
No work life balance expect to work 12 to 16 hours without compensation 
Lack of training now with emphasis on India, U.S. employees learn by procedures and figuring out on your own while India to recieve procedures and shown how through using webex and phone

pros: Good benefits package, nice office location (downtown Toronto)
cons:
It is a large organization, it can be a challenge navigating the bureaucracy to get things done.
24/7 support of application is required.
No room for growth.
High turnaround.

review_title: Not the Worst, but Not the Best
pros: Nice people, decent benefits, flexible work options (ex work from home)
cons: Low pay, almost impossible to advance without moving to a different position, constant turnover and shuffling of employees and management (I have had more than 10 managers in 6 years), almost no employee recognition, stealthy layoffs that seem to happen very frequently, very poor communication from senior management to lower level employees

job_title: Mutual Fund Accountant in Boston, MA
pros: Good benefits such as health and dental insurance, etc.  Most large companies offer similar benefits so this isn't a good reason to work for State Street.  Good starting job to learn the financial services industry
cons: Bad learning experience since they are constantly reducing job responsibilities so that your not learning anything new.  With the current job structure you have to continue to find a new position every year and that isn't always possible.  Your job is always in jeopardy with all of these layoffs every year and sending all of these jobs to India on a continual basis.  Layoffs create an unrealistic amount of work for most that are still working at State Street.  You have to expect to work at least 50-60 hours a week.

pros: Being able to work from home creates excellent flexibility.
cons: Upper management can be out of touch at times. Does not pay competitive wages to new graduates. No more tuition reimbursement or rewards programs.

job_title: Vice President, Quantitative Analysis in Boston, MA
pros: A stepping stone for the interns/juniors looking to learn the basics and perhaps those who have no family so could spend 70 hours on pointless projects to look busy and make their clueless boss look good.
cons: A lot! Agree with another reviewer about the "all white boy club" culture. Not diverse at all despite all diversity bluffing. The middle level management is usually unqualified and clueless. All what matters to senior management is being part of their gang. No matter your qualification, you will be marginalized if not in the gang. Management treats employees like their subjects. Usually Lots of politics and depending on who your boss is, work environment could be hostile and ineffective with lots of favoritism. Overall, inefficient in almost every process. The HR only tries to protect the company and doesn't care much when employees raise issues.

job_title: Assistant Vice President in Boston, MA
pros: Good Benefits especially flexible time
cons: Minimal annual raises, a demoralized environment especially with the ongoing layoffs.

review_title: Potential to be so much more
pros: Recent upturn in client focus due to market downturn. Overdue but the opportunity to start focusing on quality rather than 'ticking the boxes' is positive. Watch this space.
cons:
Fragmented departments. Seems a bit like mission impossible at times, unless a solution path to a problem is clearly defined they all seem to disavow all knowledge or ownership.
Over abundance of middle management & VPs -hampering effectiveness.

review_title: It has good qualities and bad
job_title: Fund Accountant Associate I in Boston, MA
pros: Very easy work.  Pretty relaxed environment.  Good health care and 100% 401k match up to 6% of your salary.
cons: Salary is absolutely horrible!!!!  I have worked here for a year and a half and had no raise last year 2009 and a little bonus.  Impossible to even get a job within the company.  More jobs are being posted, so hopefully something will happen in my favor but I doubt it.  State Street gives no incentive to go above and beyond.

review_title: Good only for a few months...
