The employment perks include various activities, games, and having that "corporate" feel , which can be a valuable experience when working in teams. State Street has a good name recognition and its' experience can be valuable to anyone's resume when looking elsewhere. Also, vacation time is on point.
cons: It is a revolving door of turnover. These young people you meet will eventually leave for better opportunities (usually less than 1 year employed), as long as they are motivated to move up in their career. State Street has availability for middle management due to this turnover, but the pay will not be worth the added stress. The pay is absolutely the biggest gripe I've ever heard. For the company to target Accounting, Finance, Business majors - all of us want more out of our job. With the promotions that do happen, there's no real incentive except for a resume boost.  I have been involved with several State Street activities, but that's ultimately the reason I left: better opportunities to grow and to earn a better living.

review_title: Was able to learn a lot but very stressful and eventually burned out.
pros:
Good for college graduates looking for a decent entry level job into the market. 
Ok pay.
Good benefits.
cons:
Stressful.
Long hours.
Many daily deadlines.
Failure only job, no matter how well you do you are bound to slip up and are always one button away from a big mistake.

pros: Company benefits and policies are great.  Flex time and working from home is allowed, but it is at the discretion of your manager.
cons: There are a lot of opportunities within the organization if you're located in Boston.  But if you're in the satellite areas, there may not be.  The company seems to like to re-organize and lay off people much more often than most companies.

review_title: Not a culture that promotes growth
job_title: Senior Performance Analyst in Somerville, MA
pros: Education reimbursement. Depending on the people you get to work with in your team, it can be a fun environment, and good camaraderie.
cons: Generally managers don't want to lose their best employees, so they don't promote professional growth, at least it's not part of the culture, but if you're lucky to get a good manager they will help you. You have to network and seek new positions/departments to grow professionally, if growth within the team/department is made hard from the manager.

pros: Top 100 employers in Toronto
cons: Mid level managers is pretty bad with their people skills or managing people. Maybe just my team though. Our department doesn't promote from within the team, for some reason they tend to hire supervisors from the outside and we the associates train the supervisors which doesn't make total sense at all.

pros: Work from home capabilities. Good "foot in the door" to the professional world out of school.
cons: My manger is great, many other managers seem to be less so. Pay is below industry average. Some teams have rapid turnover making the job overwhelming. Other teams have very little turnover making promotions unlikely.

pros: The people you work with are young and energetic. Management knows how to complete tasks and are fully experienced in their specific field. Certain parts of the month can be less stressful. Also working at State Street provides opportunities to learn more about the global market and the ongoings in the 401(k) world. Tuition reimbursement is available for those who seek it. Looks good on your resume.
cons: Month end period is trecherous with non-stop work. Managers sometiem lack patience with new hires as well as long time workers. Salaries don't go up much regardless of years of experience. Communication is lacking many times and duties are often assigned to multiple people. Managers don't encouraged workers to take classes outside of State Street's own curriculum. Work life balance doesn't exist... period! Work before life. Since managers ususally know what they are doing, they forget that some people, expecially newcomers, don't know as much as them. Managers get frustrated when an employee hasn't completed a work that he/she was never taught. Most employees complain about poor pay and that creates a negative environement. The work is simply data entry and very monotonous. There is no space for fresh ideas/creativity, or insight. Portfolio accountants can harldy seperate themselves from their colleagues, unless they do a ridiculous amount of overtime. It appears that there is no room to grow and no furthere promotions after the manager position.

review_title: If no other job can be found - I guess take it - but you will hate it.
pros: It is an easy job to get right out of college, you do not need a degree in accounting - or any business related field.  It is good experience if you have a degree in marketing, communciations, sociology, etc. and want to get some background in accounting or other business realated field.  Although hiring is at  a standstill or very slow right now, it was once an easy job to get and once the economy turns around, it is a decent place to get your foot in the door.  The role of a fund accountant is very non stressful.  You will do an average of about 1 hour of work a day, the rest of the time is used to shop, search the internet, or stare at your desk.  For some people, this will be extremely boring, but for others it is a relaxed atmosphere where most poeple will be at about your age (young college grad 21-24.)  It is a very diverse atmosphere where you can learn interpersonal skills that will be beneficial when looking for better jobs.  Tuition reimbursement is a huge plus - and should be taken advantage of to lead to better things..
cons: The compensation is downright embarassing.  The low pay leads to a horrible work place moral where almost everyone hates their job.  Promotions are soley based upon how long you have been there, and the slum stay the longest (your boss will most likeley be your boss because they couldn't get a job elsewhere),  The top talent will almost always leave within 1 year, when they become fed up with the job and realize they can make more money elsewhere and take on a more important role.  Your voice will almost never be heard - you can be replaced very easily - especially in this poor economy where people are just looking for any type of job.  Getting paid 33,000 a year - about $15-16 an hour for a college graduate is insanely low but once again - you can be replaced easily.  The job itself will almost never transfer to useful knowledge.  The work consists of clicking a few excel macros (trust  me you will hate them) everyday - thats about it. Management does not do a good job of telling you whey you do things - just making sure you do them.  I would not recommend this job unless you can not find anything else.

pros: Flexible work schedule, exposure to financial industry, laid back atmosphere, good stepping stone for opportunity in other financial firm .
cons: Terrible salary (keep your second job), few advancement opportunity, high turnover, management don’t really care about employee development, in other word take the experience adjust your resume and run.

review_title: Good place to grow depending on where you end up.
pros: Good benefits, opportunities grow, mentoring program available, Convenient locations, company is working towards flexible work arrangements, recognition for good performance.
cons: The most common complaint I have heard from staff is the poor compensation.  Competitors pay higher salaries, which makes retaining talented staff difficult.  Also the recent business transformation process has been managed a bit sloppy.

pros: State Street is a great financial company that everyone has heard of.  You learn a lot and there is a whole lot of potential for growth within the company.  The benefits are good and they also match up to 6 percent toward your retirement which in this economy is amazing.
cons: Very stressful job.  They pile a whole lot of work on to you and don't pay you enough for it!

pros: There are lots of opportunites for growth within the company being that it is so large. The try to create a fun work environment and have quite a few employee appreciation events.
cons: The salary is very low compared to industry averages.  They could do a better job at paying for top talent. High turnover, which can create stress on those who stick around.

review_title: Only take a job @ SS if you are desperate for $$$ or a newby from undergrad and need experience
pros:
-large global company recognition meaning it looks better on the resume than a small shop where no one knows it
-opportunity to work with other large banks, hedge funds, private equity, and influencial finance companies in the field like Morgan Stanley, Goldman Sachs, HBK, DE Shaw, etc. 
-there are in class training available for topics like Swaps, CMBS, Options, Derviatives, etc. 
(people loved to take the Bloomberg classes free snacks, people abused it where they bring hockey sized bags to literally rob the place, lolol, not really but it looks bad on the company where you send a bunch of people for training and some come out with grocery bags full of junk food)
-get to learn the ropes at a financial institution
-not extremely hard to get a job here in comparision to like a Goldman, MS, Credit Suisse, ie. Tier 1 banks that you hear all the time on the news
-good benefits, pretty everything was covered under my insurance
-company contributes to your pension
-can get promoted or advancement rather early because a lot of people leave once they have some decent experience for better paying companies
cons:
-back to one of my points above, as its not extremely hard to get a position at SS this is probably why the pay sucks, competiting firms like Citco use to pay $10K more for the same work and crap you'd get a SS. does that make any sense probably not. 
-luckily, I didn't have this issue but I've heard managers on the floor where they require their subordinates to take an hour lunch just so they don't have to pay them for it(non paying lunch and breaks required). there is a lot of work typically and most people eat at their desk so they can finish it and go home early or at least a decent time. depending on the time you are probably guaranteed to do some sort of OT especially during month end, quarter end, year end, and etc. this is really where you get your pay when you are a junior or a senior. you get 1.5x pay, some juniors, seniors, can honestly no lie make more than there managers or supervisors if they do crazy amounts of OT.
-raises are LIMITED to 10% of your salary. meaning there is a max. raise you can get. 10% sounds like a LOT for a raise when you get promoted from a junior to a senior position but when your salary is so low the 10% is actually really not much from an absolute POV. 
-once you hit Supervisor you do NOT get OT which sucks because you still have to put in a lot of time. I've heard of people leaving around 5-6PM cause basically because you are not being paid for the additional time you put in. why would you stay around? come on SS you gotta change these dumb rules. 
-this one is kinda releated to the above, due to the lack of $$$ this leads to high turnover within the company. 
-on my team alone I'd say probably 7-9 people have left either for a higher paying job, terminated, or layed off, my hiring manager left before me. 
-senior management loves to play political games, stop these games, when a client ask for things don't just say YES 100% of the time. you need to understand that things don't come easy and need time to put together and it takes time and effort. 
-basically the biggest "CON" for working at SS is the pay sucks, real easy to break it down. you come to SS more for the experience and title and then you get out once you get those things. besides that things are pretty good.

review_title: A great company to work for
pros: I have had a very positive experience working at State Street. They have a knack of gathering great employees who share the same goals which leads to lots of fun and team spirit. You also gain access to global assignments which is great for your career and variety.
cons: Sometimes difficult working for a US company in terms of decision making otherwise working at State Street has been one of my favourite jobs.

job_title: Fund Administrator, Associate II in Kansas City, MO
pros: Good benefits, employees start with 3 weeks vacation + 9 regular holidays + 3 floating holidays.  Other benefits are exceptional, although most benefits are applicable based on team/department needs.  Great training ground for people fresh out of college.  Good introduction to global organization.
cons: Management and HR could use a lot of work in many aspects. Parking costs $630+ per year.  Very corporate and political mentality, employees are simply numbers to the people that matter. Description of benefits, work/life and other policies were misleading or explained in a misleading manner.

review_title: Do not take a job with them
pros:
Good work life balance. 
Good training.
cons:
The salary is crap and when you get promoted you are told that we cannot give you anymore as we just don't have the money but please take on the extra responsibility and extra hours for nothing because you should just love to work for us !!  
There isn't much in terms of progression.

pros: Great internship for a student coming out of freshman year. You learn about investment and how brokers interact.
cons: After 3 months you'll be bored of processing trades. It becomes monotonous after a while. Management likes to pretend you're an actual employee and doing you a favor by hiring you, but they really are just paying interns 11 an hour to do the work of full time employees who should be given more.

pros: Good work/life balance, including hour worked per week and FLEX arrangement (work from home). Depending on your workload, you can have numerous internal and network opportunities if you have the time to do so.
cons: Depending on your placement, you might have a favorable team with fair managers who don't play favorite. Unfortunately, they have some awful VPs that play favorite. Your hard work might not get recognized or you might have less work/life balance than other people if you aren't in your upper management's favor.

pros:
Great people.  
Had pretty good benefits, although they continue to make cuts to them.
Supportive of the communities in which they operate.
cons:
Constant lay offs.
Senior management changes priorities and strategy at the drop of a dime with little to no communication.
Overly complicated.
Unrealistic expectations.
Don't value their employees.  Consistently set people up for failure.
Focused on cost to the point where many goals become unachievable.
So slow.  Incredibly difficult to get things accomplished.

review_title: No "air cover" and too many politics
pros: Multiple locations; flexible work arrangements; capability to work at home; when it's going well, it's going very well. If you connect with the right people, you can be successful
cons: What's a pro is also a con. Very political environment. One day you are in, the next day you could be out. There is zero training of managers when they are brought in. Little emphasis on ensuring employee satisifaction. Surveys sent to staff regarding employee engagement seem to be just for show. There's never any action taken. Pay increases and bonus are unpredictable.

review_title: A good place to stay 3-5 years
pros: There is room to grow through internal movement, but you have to be aggressive about it.  You need to move around business areas and not within team to really become valuable and learn more skills otherwise it will be difficult to market yourself to other companies.
cons: Terrible pay increases when you move internally.  You have to leave after 3-5 years to really move ahead and get comprable market pay.

pros: This place is very relaxed, depending on your department. Usually work is a little slow, so leaving you time to browse the internet for a while, however when its busy, you are SWAMPED! Work is not very challenging but fun.
cons: Pay is very low compared to competitors such as Keybank, JP Morgan Chase, Commerce Bank etc. most of those companies are starting off at 40k where as Statestreet is starting 28K in KC. Most of my co-workers have two jobs

review_title: Driving Positive Change For the Future
pros: Jay Hooley recently appeared on NECN, his comments drove home for me the following.  Our company is involved in the community, creates an inclusive work environment, and cares about the environment. We also do a great job for our clients and why I am proud to work here.
cons: The demands and continued drive to succeed can result in pressure and stress during challenging times yet it is the same challenges that provided most with the opportunities to succeed. Expectations are high but what would you expect from a leader.

review_title: A cost centre and a life of constant cuts
pros: Quick progression and increased responsibility.  This is a great place if you're lucky and you want to push on.  They're more than happy for people to step up as there's nowhere near enough people to cope with the workload.
cons: Pay is fairly terrible and everything is your problem, management don't want to know.  In an industry that is suffering further cuts and numerous outsourcing projects State Street just don't want to be in the Fund Accounting business anymore, regardless of it actually being their bread and butter.

job_title: Senior Vice President in Boston, MA
pros: There are varied opportunities for employees willing to look for them.  Extensive operations across the globe and across multiple business lines provides a breadth of experiences without leaving the Bank.
cons: there is minimal training pursued.  People are assigned to roles base upon reputation and contacts rather than skill set and abilities.  Finance Management does not engage front line managers in employee development decisions.

review_title: Lots of room for advancement- if you're smart
pros: I started here right out of college as an associate I. It was just entry level processing work and the pay isn't super high but within 2 months there was talks of promotion. My AVP had started at my position 5 years prior. Great benefits, lots of opportunities to learn with a team budget.
cons: Low starting pay, if other people aren't doing their job then you have to make sure it's done. But that is recognized at least.

job_title: Assistant Vice President in New York, NY
pros: Flexible work arrangements (i.e. work from home), 4 paid weeks of vacation, decent benefits programs, strong mobility programs.
cons: Salaries for in-house promoted employees do not match market rates.

pros: The put a lot of effort into developing  younger employees and willing to give career changers a shot.   Good benefits, vacation time. Motivated employees can move ahead pretty quickly,l.  A wide range of opportunities in the company or work for clients. If you have a desire to move, there are opportunities all over the county and world wide.
cons:
Low pay for associates and officers and above  are overworked. 

Systems are outdated.  Too much emphasis on offshoring jobs.

review_title: Don't get sucked in... get a year or two of experience and get out
pros: On the operations side, they offer a safe (yet low paying) job with the opportunity to move up a few levels before becoming stuck as a mid level manager.
cons: After a year of real, professional experience, your job becomes expendable and the management knows it.  With no real pay raises and a lack of respect, it becomes a depressing place to work at.  Don't get fooled by their promotions and promises like I did.

review_title: Stay Far Away - You will regret working here
job_title: Associate II in Jersey City, NJ
pros:
Good health insurance
Parking (except it is not free).
cons: I went from having a completely uninvolved manager to a micromanager. This place is a joke. It is data entry at best. I understand so many are desperate, and will take any job with the current economic conditions, but please, don't make the same mistake as me. The work is boring, repetitive, and most departments are the same - except for managers, that is. My current manager is suffocating and she wants to constantly communicate and be the best of friends. In fact, one manager considered us all "family." No! The entire department gives me little room to breathe.

job_title: Fund Accountant, Associate I in Houston, TX
pros: Good work-life balance, fair pay for your job. OT is controlled and one can always have personal time after work.The job is stable and one can expect that there will not be challenging issues once they get used to the job. So it will be a good place for those who like a peace life.
cons: Not much on personal career development, especially for who seek for professional career path. Payment is not high enough to attract and retain talent. This may partly due to the nature of job. Fund accountant may not require a high calibre person.

pros:
1.Very great work/life balance, or should I say too great.if it is not in peak time, you only need to spend like 2 hours max to do the daily job. and you can do whatever you want for the rest of the time. 
2. In BPO or AIS departments, 90% of the employees are girls who just graduated from college/\university. So it is good if you are single guy  and looking for gf.  They love foreigners!!!
3. Good for female new graduates!!! Stable job, friendly work environment.
4. Most of the managers are easy going. They do not really have too many rules in the office. Well, some of them do not know /care what their teams are actually doing. So they rely heavily on some of the associate 2 or AM.
cons:
1. Like other SS division, very low pay and practically no bonus . If you are assigned from Boston or UK. Then it is a paradise here. Company will pay for your rent. I know all the experts or VP lives either in luxury hotels/condos. you got the $ salary instead of ￥. But if you hired locally. Then it definitely is a nightmare. The compensation is below the local average!!! After deducting your rent and food spending, you basically have no money left!!!
2. Limited career advancement. Honestly, if you and your supervisor/unit head are buddy-buddy. Then you should be promoted very quickly. But most of the time,  senior management keeps hiring team leader externally instead of promoting us internally. They like ppl who have fancy experience but do not care how much they know of custody/fund accounting. And junior associates just felt like they are just a bunch of ass kissers who pretend to know everything.
3. Daily job is like an assembly line. You can work here for quite a few months and have no clue what you r doing.

pros: Nice office with a good canteen. Decent internet connection for looking up other jobs.
cons:
One of the worst experiences of my life. Irish operation are viewed as a bunch of idiots by the rest of the company (isn't far from the truth), which translates into bad pay along with zero rewards or support. Staff don't have a clue or care about what they do. Stifling management structure who also don't have a clue. 

Promotion is about time done and participation in horrendous office politics, rather than actual talent or ability.

If you have a lack of passion and aspersion then go for it!

review_title: Wasted too much time getting paid too little
pros: Opportunity to work from home (depending on which team you're on), decent benefits (health, vacation, 401k match, sick pay). Good to put on your resume as it is a well known corporation.
cons: Below average pay, lack of technology, difficult to move up, poor management, high turnover rate, lots of favoritism, no job security (layoffs), raises were a joke, forced to work 50+ hours a week (depending on which team you're on).

job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Boston, MA
pros:
Large company and generally easy hiring process, so easy to get in. 
Good for H1B as they would process it and also offer Green Card processing
cons:
1. Heavy on bureaucracy, too many non-lean processes/ticketing systems.
2. Lack of vision in senior management and leadership, mass confusion and mass exodus from company since last 8-10 months
3. Pays less than most companies in the area
4. No work life balance
5. Due to easy interview process, many incapable employees

review_title: Good place if you really need a job
pros: Position Pays for Overtime, people I work with are fun and easy going
cons: Work is very redundant, minimal reimbursement for furthering your education (MBA/MSF), turnover rate is high even in a recession. You never get a real sense that you have the ability to move up in the organization.

review_title: The worst working experience of my life
pros: If you are here to play politics and unskilled with regards to the financial market then you can have a career, promotion and you can expect to reach the highest level that your incompetence can achieve
cons: You can hide, do nothing and bring home you cash. The company is so poorely managed that none will realize

pros:
Room for growth
Relaxed Atmosphere
Ample Parking/ Easy access to public transportation
Work from Home access
Flex Time
If you are a hard worker, and get involved and noticed in the community, you can move up quickly.
cons:
Salary!!!!

I enjoy everything about this job, except for the salary!  It is almost impossible to live off of what they pay, especially if you live in the city.  Also, they say that having a lower salary is complemented by being able to accrue overtime, however there is rarely any overtime available, so it is really a moot point.

pros: Good place to learn the business. Management is flexible with regards to your personal life. Lots of different areas to move around and learn the business.
cons: CEO only cares about lining his own pockets with more money. Outsourcing is just growing there more and more. Low pay. No loyalty.

pros: They had a cool kickball tournament.
cons: In the Kansas City mutual fund group, not only will you be kept from progressing, but you will take the blame for management's errors if you aren't high up on their ladder or a 'favorite.' The headquarters in Boston are completely clueless as to how things are run in the KC location and if they saw how backwards and incredibly ignorant their management staff was, they'd be wise to shut down the entire operation. Employee turnover was weekly...which is pathetic.

pros: Plenty of opportunities for management to give associates and junior managers a good kicking
cons: Cutting costs is the only game in the company. Experienced staff are used to train mainly offshored staff (usually India) before making them redundant. High attrition rates in in India (HCL and SSSS) means State Street loses both experienced staff and the newly trained, as they don't wait around to train their successors. This impacts on client service, but hey, State Street saves a packet on UK costs.  Current and prospective clients should be very scared.  A ticking time-bomb...

pros: Great starter job as a graduate and great location in Drogheda and SJRQ. Opportunities to advance to associate 2 or supervisor available with hard work
cons:
Apparent that a number of colleagues did not understand the fundamentals of what they were doing. 

Did not feel comfortable asking questions for fear of backlash 

Favoritism around holidays and difficult to get days around holiday seasons

review_title: Good benefits, flexible WFH option, poor work pay
pros:
Great vacation time benefits: 3 weeks of vacation starting, 3 personal days, 1 birthday day off, 1 earned wellness day. 5 sick days and optional up to 1 additional vacation week buy.

Depending on your department and manager, WFH can be arranged ( I think up to 2 WFH days per week)

offers fitness membership fees, sports club fees, outdoor activity season pass fees, and races membership fees reimbursement
cons:
Outsourcing many work which resulted in reduction of workforce.  company morale was low when I left. 

Salary is below industry standard.

pros: Lots of opportunities around the Boston area
cons: The organization is so large, employees may feel like their lost.  The computer infrastructure for employees was fairly old when I was working there, although it may be better now.  This led to some crashes every now and then.  My biggest gripe was with the User ID/Password access which took weeks to get after my employment.  At one point in time there were 3 employees using the same access rights.

review_title: not a bad place to be
pros:
-education reimbursement 100%
-large company -internal mobility - you can post for a new position every year .
-laid back
-nice people young
-good programs for mentoring and career development if you chose to take advantage.
-2 paid volunteer days per year
cons:
One disadvantage is the pay is lower than average.
Moving from senior to account manager most people take a pay cut because of the overtime you can get as a senior vs salary of an account manager.

you have to work whenever the stock market is open.

review_title: Good for entry-level but ot much else
pros:
These pros would make the jobs worth the effort for younger people looking for work:
- Great benefits package
- Good colleagues
- Flexible schedule
- Adequate time off
cons:
-Not much room for career advancement
-HR doesn't really care about handling employee complaints
- Senior management is seldom aware of daily issues
- Salaries are below norm

pros: good work and life balance. laid back environment. managers try to avoid overtime by all means, which means employees get to go home on time.
cons: many inexperienced and undedicated colleagues. not much training given in the beginning. learn as you go is the motto. many employees don't take their work seriously.

pros: The day to day work  environment is very comfortable and stable.  Once the processes are learned, the job can often become quite easy at times.
cons: Growth opportunities are not communicated well will employees.  Compensation level does not seem to be on par with peers.  Also, the makes it a less desirable place to start someones career.

pros: the only real benefit I can think of other then a stead paycheck is that its a global company that everybody has heard of
cons: there are to many to name.  There is littel growth opportunity, everybody is just tryign to fidn a new job the entire tiem they are workign here and the raises and or promotiosn are non existent

pros: Large company, lots of mobility. The size of the company allows you the opportunity to gather a lot of experience in a short period of time.
cons: Salaries tend to be a bit lower then the industry standard but still competitive. Perhaps an increase in the percentage of work from home staff would make up for this.

review_title: It is a great place for someone with no experience.
job_title: Custody Specialist in Kansas City, MO
pros: They are a great place to use as a stepping stone. You do not have to work all that hard if that is the type of work you are looking for.
cons: People are lazy and management tends to do nothing about it except give more work to the hard workers yet everyone is paid the same.

review_title: Good place to build a career once you get past the lower levels.
pros: True meritocracy.  If you add value to the company you will be rewarded and advance.  Most Vice Presidents and above are good, but obviously not all.  If you are good with people and managing internal relationships you can be very successful.
cons: Difficult to advance from the very lower levels.  Fairly stressful work especially as cost cutting hits the industry.  Fair amount of politics as with any large organization.

pros:
The hours are great which include time to work from home. 
Many of the people are very nice with executives and leaders very accessible. 
The benefits are excellent and the website is well designed and easy to use.
A good starting point for someone wanting to a career in the financial industry.
cons:
The pay isn't very good at all. On the low end of industry standard. 
Strange working hours can make it difficult to have a personal life.

review_title: Pay too low. Turnover extrememly high.
job_title: Fund Accountant in Kansas City, MO
pros: Depending on the department you are in, there are some great people to work for and with within the company. Great place to get your foot in the door.
cons: The pay is incredibly low, and the stress/workload quite high, comparatively. Because of this there is a huge amount of turnover, which leaves employees who stick around the duty of training a lot of new employees and doing the work of two people.

job_title: Client Ops (Fund Accountant III) in Kansas City, MO
pros: This company offers good health insurance much better than other companies.  The vacation that is offered is also reasonable.
cons: There were a number of cons however the main two are the pay scale and the ability for work place advancement.  Advancement isn't truly based on skill but who you know or who likes you.

pros:
Less work pressure
CAB+ Food coupons
cons:
No learning
Poor management, No growth, Poor KYC process, No room for learning new things
Higher management does not have any technical knowledge
No promotions , lot of biased,  encourage is there for same community
Not a great place to work, if your looking for learning and exploring  it is data entry kind of job (KYC/AML)

pros: State Street is solid company with good benefits.  Overall, a nice group of people to work with, made some good friends there.  Like many large companies, there is room for advancement, although the path is not necessarily clear or direct.
cons: It could be unique to the division I worked in, or a result of the manager I reported to, but it felt like we were all in our own silos.

job_title: Operations Specialist in North Quincy, MA
pros: Really good benefits such as your birthday off and they reimburse you up to $200 for any gym membership. Good company to start up your career and gain experience.
cons: Expect to do more work than what they pay you for, expect to work long stressful hours. Coming from someone with a bachelors degree, you will definitely feel like you deserve to be paid more. Only the upper people get the big cash, and there is a lot of off-shoring and laying off.

review_title: Big company with al ot of opportunity, but the company does not pay well
pros: Big company with a lot of opportunities to learn and grow. Very flexible work from home plan. I currently work from home full time.
cons: State Street looks to pay you as little as they can to keep you. When I got promoted it was only because I threatened to leave. They will not promote or give bonuses based on merit.

review_title: Highly political and a cultural nightmare
pros: May be flexible work arrangements if you get to work for the right manager
cons:
Constant organizational change
implementation of unnecessary technology.  Calling helpdesk for a password reset seems like a mission impossible scenario. 
Constant micromanagement. 
Managers having FOMO if they find their employees talking to others outside the team.

review_title: Great people, super monotonous, Caring managers
pros: The people who work are like minded individuals who strive for the best in terms of their career and relationships. The management was great as they focused on their employees careers and operations.
cons: Depending on what job you have here, some of the work can be monotonous.  Part of my job was to contact other state street employees and file inquiries regarding issues with trades. These inquiries were sent back and forth with no solution.

pros:
Love how everyone respects one another.
Fun exciting work environment.
Flexible work hours.  
Have the opportunity to learn something new about the industry each day.
cons:
Salary is low compared to other companies. 
Need to have better tuition reimbursements.   Currently it's 5,000 max for a yr and you have to remain working there another year in order to get it.

review_title: Good place to start right out of college.
pros: Great management. The team atmosphere is very endearing, everyone gets along and easy going. Management micro-manages most new hires and helps with any solutions.
cons: Advancement in the company is solely based on tenure and experience. Sometimes favoritism plays a role in the hiring process but most often, the longer you've been here the easier it is to move up.

pros: Good work life balance, friendly folks within SSGM.  SSGM promoted self-reliance and independent work within some fun teams.  Some flexibility moving between groups as well.
cons: Pay and promotions are hard to come by.  Other employers seem to have more transparent pay and promotion targets than State Street, where communication on these fronts was less clear.

job_title: Associate II in Walnut Creek, CA
pros: Great place to gain some experience for a new college grad.  At least when I was there, the people were awesome, which is exactly what I miss the most.  Other than that, the only other thing I can say about that place and the position is the hours were great.
cons: I did not feel like there was much room for advancement, and the base salary was down right terrible.  I know for a fact that an entry level job is San Francisco would be at least a 10-15K increase.

review_title: Shareholders are the only group matters today.
job_title: Assistant Vice President in Boston, MA
pros: Ok benefits, organized, a job, open for change
cons: No or minimal raises, cut bonuses even if company is doing good, killing motivation

review_title: Good starting company, most should leave after a year.
job_title: Senior Associate in Kansas City, MO
pros:
Easy to get hired
Good benefits
Well known name(not always a plus)
Does offer good work/life balance for some areas
cons:
Low pay
Limited advancement
Constant reorganization
Poor management/infighting/lack of leadership
Specialized business units result in newer employees never getting very good at their jobs, are forced to stay in one area.

job_title: SEC Yield Analyst, Associate II in South Boston, MA
pros: Work/life balance is great- rarely work 40 hours/ week except during month end, and you are paid time and a half for any overtime. There is opportunity for growth, usually promoted after one year. Overall- a good starting spot, don't get too comfortable!
cons: Starting salary is very low. Groups are often understaffed due to high rate of turnover and its incredibly time consuming to hire someone new, if they even keep a position open after someone leaves.

job_title: Senior Associate, Tax in Quincy, MA
pros:
* Flexible work schedule and location
* Good for working moms
* Good selection of benefits
* Good place to start a career
* Encourage training and self development
cons:
* Can be political
* Self evaluation process too standardized.  Many parts of it seem more tailored to people in
senior management positions and not relevant to lower level employees who do more routine work.
* Advancement can be very slow
* Constant restructuring promotes unstable environment and can hurt morale.

pros: There are plenty of opportunities to move around the organization and try new things. There is a  good work life balance and excellent flex work options.
cons: The long standing tradition and hierarchical nature of financial services can make it tough to get things done. It is better in some parts of the organization than others.

review_title: Great opportunity for college grads but
pros: Upward mobility. Work from home 3 days a week and vacation package starts at 4 weeks.
cons: Culture, no work life balance, COEs are awful. You have to reach out to too many ppl and departments to get things done. Nothing improves.

review_title: Low pay and terrible leadership make Fund Admin Staff  wanna jump ship
pros: Flex Time; very family- friendly firm (gotta compensate for all the negatives- see below).
cons:
NAV workpapers too manual.
Was told "the firm is lean" before I started: terrible salary, terrible raise (if any), terrible bonuses.
Threats of RIFs always in the air.
Expensive health insurance.
Sone ineffective VPs in PE/ Hybrid admin space.
Incompetent IT staff/ HelpDesk; if you have an IT issue be prepared to be shuffled between multiple technicians and have your issue resolved in a week (!).
Never had an exit interview.

pros: I get to work from home three days a week, have potlucks, and flexible work hours. I just have a cool boss and team. Competitive 401K, okay health insurance premiums, tuition reimbursements, accumulative vacation hours, personal days, etc.
cons: Depending on your team, work could be repetitive or challenging. Work could get stressful and a lot of overtime if needed. Can't really plan things during the week because we could get unexpected overtime due to late prices.

review_title: Good place to START your career
pros:
- Good place to start your career. They offer tuition reimbursement.
- 6% match on 401K and other good benefits.
- Work from Home arrangements.
cons:
- Little to no room for career advancement.
- Very low pay.
- Could be in for long hours sometimes.

review_title: Fund Accountant are underpaid, but underworked.
pros: Easy to get an entry level position. Not a bad way to get your foot in the door. Fund Accountant is an easy job.
cons: The pay for this position is low and it can be hard to live on it in Boston. Other Boston companies know what fund accountants at State Street do, which is backoffice grunt work.

pros:
1. Looks good on the CV
2. Sound executive corporate management
3. well considered strategic leadership
cons:
1. Unwilling to promote
2. Heavy with under-qualified middle management (legacy of a tight celtic tiger employment market and restrictive Irish labour practices)
3. Non-US offices considered to be 'work-houses', with little attention given to recognising talent.

pros: The number reason to work at State Street is the culture. There is a strong focus on promoting a team-oriented work environment and management is typically very supportive of the work/personal needs of employees. The work/life balance is great, including flexible work from home arrangements.
cons: Compensation for position is not as competitive as comparable positions at other financial firms. Verbal claims by firm of "identifying and retaining key talent" are not supported by payscale.

pros: Good place to gain experience in the corporate world.  The benefits are great and it is a solid company to work for.
cons: Pay isn't that great and hours can be very long.  Opportunities for advancement are limited and there are too many obstacles preventing people for reaching the next level in their career.

pros:
-Plenty of networking opportunities
-Great opportunities for career development
-Always learning
-Great insight into the industry
cons: -All the pros are contingent upon who your manager is

review_title: Become a cog in a big machine
job_title: Investor Services Associate in Boston, MA
pros: Stability and good corporate resources.  SSGA is an attractive division of State Street, and there is reputable economy of scale within this giant bank.  Not the worst company to launch career but I could not envision fostering long career there (maybe it's just me?).
cons: Zero interest in true employee career development, uninspiring middle management, becoming a cog in the machine or just another number which equally speaks to the size of this bank, but also the disconnect between upper management and those who work there.

pros: Work from home but not much else
cons: Poor transparency and communication from management on down. Long work hours, low pay and very minimal raise or not at all. Transferring from one department to another is a very long process.

pros: I worked here for over 10 years and had an overall positive experience.  I worked with some great people across several different teams.  There are opportunities to learn, grow as an employee, get involved with department projects and community volunteer events.
cons: Employee benefit costs kept getting higher for the employee cost portion over the last 2-4 years I was there.  Although the company supports flexible work arrangements it is up to the individual department and or management team to approve.

pros: The job is great right out of college and for a few years after.  Its filled with young working professionals who like to party after work.  The work life is about the only pro
cons:
-Awful pay
-Offices and desk are clustered
-Too many "VPs"
-Office space type of job where you have people you don't know always asking you things

pros:
Work life balance is a huge thing so flex work from home is a normal occurrence after a year of work. 
Diversity drive is also being stepped up by management
cons: Older company with older employees , hard to invigorate change but many attempts are in process . Not a great environment for fresh talent , great for people with families though.

pros: Provides valuable experience when applying to other custodians and banks
cons: Completely unwilling to spend money improving poor and noncompetitive salaries, recruit additional staff to ease intensive workloads, develop outdated and inferior critical business systems, and more recently even upkeep basic colleague amenities. Poor consultation with staff despite a 'speak up listen up' culture. Unable to cope with increased staff turnover and appalling replacement measures in place.

pros: At the time, the team I worked on was great.  Staff training to facilitate continuous professional development was excellent. SS promoted culture very well despite being headquartered in Boston, London staff felt engaged as participation in town Halls was encouraged.
cons: At the time  the work life balance was not favourable due to travel requirements and an ambitious Audit plan. Also some management (not all) favoured external recruitment over internal development and promotion. Even at the expense of losing talent and experienced staff.

job_title: Investment Manager Representative in Boston, MA
pros: The department i worked in had a fairly laid back atmosphere. My manager was helpful as were generally the other people i worked with.
cons: pay was not very good and opportunities for growth were few. turnover is pretty high so you will have to learn to continuously work with new people.

review_title: Overall, solid company to work for
pros:
-Friendly co-workers
-Competitive pay
-Laid-back atmosphere
-Good brand name for your resume
cons:
-Centralization
-Work can be routine
-Occasional pay cuts
-Long hours of work for current employees due to cost cutting inititatives

pros: Benefits are great, 401K is quite competitive
cons: The salary to a young proffessional is a joke.  I feel that State Street takesand unfair advantage recent college grads.  There is an exceedingly large amount of older employees who get paid far beyond the amount of new hires, but complete far less tasks and workload due to various incompetencies.

job_title: Portfolio Accountant in Kansas City, MO
pros: Great place to start out of college and gain corporate experience.  Stay for a year or two and take your experience and move on.  Nice thing is only 40 hour work weeks..
cons: Low pay, high cost for benefits, the cafeteria is very expensive and they make you pay in excess of $600 a year to park your vehicle in the parking garage.

review_title: Good place to start a career
pros: The work is low stress and the people easy to get along with. It's not an overly political work environment. Great hours in most departments. Plenty of nice perks and employee appreciation activities. Creates a very collegiate workplace.
cons: Low pay and limited opportunities for advancement based on skills. Wish that promotions were not given out due to length of employment.

pros:
- Good networking opportunities
-Tons of employee events and ways to get involved in the community
-Company sponsored volunteer events (2 paid days a year to volunteer)
-Flexible work scheduling/work from home depending on the department you're in
cons:
-Salary below average
-Raises, bonuses, promotions are not significant 
-As with a lot of companies, a lot of office politics, unequal treatment and favoritism between employees from managers.
-Employee morale affected by offshoring and frequent layoffs.

pros: State Street is a very large company with good benefits as well as a lot of promotional opportunities.  There are different career paths and options all throughout this company.
cons: It would seem State Street has very mediocre pay in comparison to other companies, unless you have been with the company for over 15 to 20 years.

job_title: Client Operations Associate in Quincy, MA
pros: Easy job to land after college. Good for experience foundation.
cons: The pay is bare minimum. Think of it more as an internship. Work is repetitive and robotic, hard to learn more than a few tasks. Long hours and low morale.

review_title: A very good place for an internship or work experience but pay is lower compared to other firms
pros: The name of statestreet is huge to have on your CV, it's a huge multinational company and the contacts you make from there are very good
cons: Doesn't pay as well as its competitors, if you are in the financial reporting department then long working hours for the first quarter of the year and not organised very well

pros: Some very smart people who understand that Services is part of Financial Services.  Move resources to support new product launches effectively. (even if at detriment of existing products)
cons: Over past 5 years have become totally quarterly goal focused.  Clients are secondary or tertiary in the equation.  Knowledge vacuum is evident as Service Standards have moved to all time low

pros: It wasn't a bad opportunity for a first job after college and I met a lot of good friends. It taught me the basics to progress on my career.
cons: The politics is abundant in Statestreet. It also doesn't harbour any nuturing of talent or free thought. There is only one way to do things and it is not your way.

review_title: Would not recommend, poor salary and very long hours
pros: Good work experience of working in a high pressured environment and being thrown in the deep end. Employees all very friendly. Good employee Benefits such as health insurance.
cons: Long hours, low salary, poor chances of progression, too much bureaucracy taking place. Intense environment to work in. would not recommend.

pros: Laid back work environment, room for growth.
cons: Pay could be better, some managers and even those at the officer level know little in comparison to the students. Its a bizarre business practice to promote those that are unable to help with the work.

review_title: Toxic culture, strong compensation.  All in all, just okay.
pros: Remuneration is fantastic and I work with many of the brightest people I've met.  Benefits are industry standard, no better and no worse than anyplace else.
cons: I work in a department where bad behavior is tolerated.  The culture is fractious, few people get along, and nearly everybody has their knives out for everybody else.  Without a concept of "team" or "we" it's a difficult place to face every day.

job_title: Professional Development Program Senior Associate in Boston, MA
pros:
-Great overview and introduction to State Street during 1st month of program
-Competitive starting salary
-Allows you to build great State Street network
cons:
-Managers use PDPs to plug holes on teams where they need extra bodies with no regard to employee's interests or professional development
-Very difficult to rotate outside of your cost-center, despite being told during interviews you can rotate in any group across bank
-No contact from program management after 1st month

job_title: Assistant Vice President in Toronto, ON
pros:
-Good Benefits (full dental, 5% RPP contributions with additional matching  for another 2%
- Worked with world class clients
-Compensated fairly and also treated with respect
cons:
-Work is in a silo, very segregated and limits ability to learn and see the bigger picture.
-Under invests in technology, no indication a next generation platform in the works.  Behind competition in many areas
-Top heavy, limited potential to advance career

review_title: Avoid Irvine IMS Division at all cost
pros: Great coworkers, vacation benefits, paid maternity, and decent pay
cons: Management does not care. Work life balance is a joke despite being touted by the parent company. Constantly have to watch your back against some managers. For such a huge company, this division is shockingly super cheap and penny pinching (I kid you not!) VERY high turnover rate. Nonexistent bonus and salary increase (if you get one). Irvine division is a sinking ship and truly, truly the worst company I had ever worked for!

pros: Overall, the people that work here are very helpful and knowledgable.  Everyone works very hard to meet deadlines in the most accurate and efficient way.
cons: Since there are deadlines and those are expected to be kept regardless of the current situation, it is difficult to train and be trained in a sufficient mannor.  Lack of training in a deadline oriented environment creates high stress levels.

review_title: Great experiance but had to move on
job_title: Business Systems Analyst in Boston, MA
pros:
- great benifits 
- they want to hire from within and also promote
cons:
- employee moral is way down after many layoffs and re-org that has everyone working much harder
- they say that they want to ensure work life balance at the top, but that doesn't trickle down to the VP or AVP level

review_title: Good starting platform for entry level, friendly culture
pros: It is good platform for those who are now to fund accounting business. People are willing to sharing ideas and experience.
cons: Not attractive yearly bonus. The salary are slightly lower than the market benchmark and i believe they are offering more training and lower the barrier for new entry. So they are not too generous in payoff staff good increment.

review_title: No real world accounting; all data entry
job_title: Fund Accountant Associate II in Kansas City, MO
pros:
Benefits
No brain power needed
Friendly co-workers
cons:
No actual accounting
No brain power needed
No one takes accountability of what should be done

pros: I had previously work in the AIS Real Estate Performance Measurement area and always impressed at how they continued to search and improve ways to service their clients.
cons: Upper management wasn't always forthcoming on how they felt about certain business groups.

pros: It does give you a good work life balance if you play your cards well. Salary is safe. There some very good people working there but not all of them will stay for long.
cons: It is too IT oriented, if you let them they squeeze as much as they can. Progressing is not easy.

review_title: Decent entry level job but really no advancement opportunities
pros:
* Can use as an opportunity for management experience since there is such high turnover.
* Schedule can be flexible depending on the team you're on & flex work is usually available.
cons:
* Hardly any promotion opportunities.
* Salary is pretty embarrassing.
* Management will really try to take advantage of you if you're a hard worker.

review_title: Great people, interesting work, and raised two awesome kids
pros: At every point in my career I have had either the career development opportunities I need to grow or the work/life balance I need to take care of my family.  The people I work with are smart, hardworking and fair.  I know many people who have left, only to immediately wish they could come back.
cons: Wish there was access to more international opportunities for people in Boston.

pros: Many opportunities if your motivated and willing to move around laterally. Global opportunities have dwindled so your best shot is in Boston.
cons: The finance division has become a victim of the overuse of consultants. Plenty of folks on staff  with good ideas and capabilities but are largely ignored over the opinions of high priced consultants (that are not always right).

pros: Teaches good skills: attention to detail, critical analysis, excel
cons: Management is sub-par, understaffing is usual, and employees are not taken good care of. The work load comes with a lot of pressure and stress during certain times, although it can be the complete opposite during other times.

job_title: Client Operations Associate II in Boston, MA
pros: The work is easy and mindless, as long as you show up everyday you will never have a problem. Also work from home is pretty convenient if your team permits it.
cons: Salary is significantly lower than industry standard, health benefits are very cheap so long as you don't use them. The biggest issue is the rampant complacency that plagues the company. Merit and hard work mean nothing, the only way to advance yourself is to stick it out as long as you possibly can. It always feels like management wants you to do more with less.

job_title: Fund Accountant in Kansas City, MO
pros:
WFH access
Business casual
Mostly friendly employees
Easy to enter
Fairly good opportunity for advancement
Good benefits
cons:
Lots of overtime
No flexible schedule (sometimes management will change your work hours and you have no choice)
Poor work-life balance
Fairly low pay
High turnover makes the job harder for those stuck with more work/training in the interim
